Add Antelope support

* sync charm-helpers to classic charms
* change openstack-origin/source default to antelope
* align testing with antelope
* add new antelope bundles
* add antelope bundles to tests.yaml
* add antelope tests to osci.yaml and .zuul.yaml
* update build-on and run-on bases

Change-Id: I8487abc15cf61abfa18d09aa73064e139fa92560

subject: Limit rax-ord launch concurrency and don't retry
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-10 17:53:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/bcb9332507d6c5b700b91358ecbc0cf65592ebd9', 'message': 'Further increase rax-ord launch timeout no retries

This region seems to take a very long time to launch nodes when we
have a burst of requests for them, like a thundering herd sort of
behavior causing launch times to increase substantially. We have a
lot of capacity in this region though, so want to boot as many
instances as we can here. In order to balance that, increase the
timeout but don't retry launch failures so that we won't ever lock a
request for multiples of the new timeout.

Also try to further mitigate the thundering herd by significantly
increasing the API "rate" (really delay) to one call per second.

Change-Id: I179ab22df37b2f996288820074ec69b8e0a202a5
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2023-03-10 18:09:44.000000000', 'files': ['nodepool/nl01.opendev.org.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/d0481326bf799eb2921e3ae073172d49aca41591', 'message': "Limit rax-ord launch concurrency and don't retry

This region seems to take a very long time to launch nodes when we
have a burst of requests for them, like a thundering herd sort of
behavior causing launch times to increase substantially. We have a
lot of capacity in this region though, so want to boot as many
instances as we can here. Attempt to reduce the effect by limiting
the number of instances nodepool will launch at the same time.

Also, mitigate the higher timeout for this provider by not retrying
launch failures, so that we won't ever lock a request for multiples
of the timeout.

Change-Id: I179ab22df37b2f996288820074ec69b8e0a202a5
"}]
commit_message:
Limit rax-ord launch concurrency and don't retry

This region seems to take a very long time to launch nodes when we
have a burst of requests for them, like a thundering herd sort of
behavior causing launch times to increase substantially. We have a
lot of capacity in this region though, so want to boot as many
instances as we can here. Attempt to reduce the effect by limiting
the number of instances nodepool will launch at the same time.

Also, mitigate the higher timeout for this provider by not retrying
launch failures, so that we won't ever lock a request for multiples
of the timeout.

Change-Id: I179ab22df37b2f996288820074ec69b8e0a202a5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/13/877113/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Under load, this region can take a very long time to launch instances, # but we have a lot of capacity here so it's worthwhile to increase the # timeout but mitigate node request delays by not retrying failures. Also # try to substantially slow the rate at which we make API calls here. launch-timeout: 1200 launch-retries: 1 rate: 1.0

commit_message:
Adds timeout for ceph command calls.

Change-Id: I8c81b1f0042181d814d5f268282b082c8a5fc217
func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/989
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-osd refs/changes/60/876960/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def safe_to_destroy(osd_id, timeout=300): ret = subprocess.call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'safe-to-destroy', osd_id ], timeout=timeout)def safe_to_stop(osd_id, timeout=300): ret = subprocess.call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'ok-to-stop', osd_id ], timeout=timeout)def reweight_osd(osd_id, timeout=300): subprocess.check_call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'crush', 'reweight', osd_id, '0' ], timeout=timeout) def destroy(osd_id, purge=False, timeout=300): subprocess.check_call([ 'ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'purge' if purge else 'destroy', osd_id, '--yes-i-really-mean-it' ], timeout=timeout)
deleted_lines: def safe_to_destroy(osd_id): ret = subprocess.call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'safe-to-destroy', osd_id])def safe_to_stop(osd_id): ret = subprocess.call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'ok-to-stop', osd_id])def reweight_osd(osd_id): subprocess.check_call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'crush', 'reweight', osd_id, '0']) def destroy(osd_id, purge=False): subprocess.check_call(['ceph', '--id', 'osd-removal', 'osd', 'purge' if purge else 'destroy', osd_id, '--yes-i-really-mean-it'])

commit_message:
Migrate ceph-osd to charmhub (luminous)

This is the stable/luminous branch of ceph-osd. It tests against
bionic-queens, bionic-rocky and bionic-train (luminous, mimic, nautilus)

Change-Id: I2344b788e841f6b7c83d20fe4c11c17f0c2bb078

The method ``neutron.agent.ovn.agent.ovsdb.get_port_qos`` should
always return 2 values, even when the LSP is not present. This
patch:
* fixes the output, returning 2 values
* catches the exception raised when the LSP is not present in the
  OVN NB database
* returns the default max_kbps and min_kbps values (0, 0).

Change-Id: I03ea78fcc5825e35c07dda1aa790769aa918dd8a

commit_message:
[OVN] Method ``get_port_qos`` should always return 2 values

The method ``neutron.agent.ovn.agent.ovsdb.get_port_qos`` should
always return 2 values, even when the LSP is not present. This
patch:
* fixes the output, returning 2 values
* catches the exception raised when the LSP is not present in the
  OVN NB database
* returns the default max_kbps and min_kbps values (0, 0).

Closes-Bug: #2009804
Change-Id: I03ea78fcc5825e35c07dda1aa790769aa918dd8a

commit_message:
Glance: Include the required glance::limit class for unified quotas

Including glance::limit for enabling unified quotas in glance
and glance::limit class requires a glance endpoint_id & password,
so adding thses 2 parameters in hieradata with their default value
'None'.

Change-Id: Ic3d2dc927f4ce2b118ee98811db74e4ac8dfb96a

commit_message:
Use standalone bootstrap playbook from tripleo-ansible

Update tripleo-heat-templates to use the bootstrap playbook from
tripleo-ansible. Removes tasks that are not refactored into the
playbook.

Depends-On: Ie36cc178c7b41a1f8988f3ab5968bc310f6f5455
Change-Id: I0e2a00e54f23c96bef8b92f571b482362028a701
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Create ephemeral heat.conf for rabbitmq/mysql config

Instead of relying on using the hiera CLI (which is now deprecated) from
tripleoclient, create a heat.conf for use with ephemeral Heat that sets
the needed configs for the rabbitmq transport_url and the mysql database
connection.

Change-Id: I12b03d9099c9434f08d42cc291f6282fc4496dbf
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/32/863432/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Create heat.conf for ephemeral Heat block when: - step|int == 1 - not ansible_check_mode|bool become: true vars: heat_ephemeral_config_dir: /var/lib/config-data/ansible-generated/heat-ephemeral/etc/heat block: - name: Create {{ heat_ephemeral_config_dir }} file: path: "{{ heat_ephemeral_config_dir }}" state: directory recurse: true mode: '0755' - name: Create heat.conf for ephemeral Heat copy: dest: "{{ heat_ephemeral_config_dir }}/heat.conf" mode: '0666' content: | [DEFAULT] transport_url="rabbit://{{ service_configs['rabbitmq::default_user'] }}:{{ service_configs['rabbitmq::default_pass'] }}@{{ fqdn_ctlplane }}:{{ service_configs['rabbitmq::port'] }}/?ssl=0" [database] connection="mysql+pymysql://heat:heat@{{ ctlplane_ip | ipwrap }}/heat?read_default_file=/etc/my.cnf.d/tripleo.cnf&read_default_group=tripleo"

commit_message:
Add a spaces concepts page

Add a page that provides a conceptual overview of how
network spaces are applied in the context of Charmed
OpenStack.

Change-Id: I7c103e8b249bdcff1c2db9a43d5f776ca4007ee7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-guide refs/changes/74/874974/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================================== Network Spaces and Charmed OpenStack ==================================== Overview -------- This document provides a conceptual overview of the role that Juju network spaces play in the deployment and management of Charmed OpenStack. A network space is a Juju object that abstracts away the OSI L3 layer. A space is created on the backing cloud to represent one or more subnets. The purpose of a space is to allow for user-defined network traffic segmentation, which can have various uses (e.g. traffic isolation as a security measure). Note: See the Juju documentation to fully explore spaces themselves. Spaces support -------------- For Charmed OpenStack, the recommended Juju backing cloud is MAAS. Spaces can be created and configured within MAAS (by associating them with VLANs and subnets) and the Juju operator can immediately make use of them when deploying or configuring OpenStack applications. GRAPHIC of MAAS web UI Bindings -------- A space is associated with an application's traffic type via the latter's corresponding "endpoint". This association is known as a "binding". This specific traffic flow is established once the endpoint is "integrated" with another application's endpoint (the juju integrate command). .. note:: Integration is the process of connecting compatible endpoints between two applications. Endpoints are discerned from a charm's metadata.yaml file. Extra bindings ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Juju has the notion of an "extra binding". Like a normal binding, an extra binding requests, via spaces, that a machine be provisioned with network connectivity to specific subnets. The intention is that the charm that supports the binding will then configure its payload service, whose consumer may be external to Juju, to listen on a certain IP address(es). This type of binding is not dependent upon an integration with another application's endpoint. .. note:: Extra bindings are explicitly declared in a charm's metadata.yaml file. Default space ------------- A default value for spaces can be set at the model level and at the application level. A model's default space is defined with the juju model-config command. If left unset, the (default) value is 'alpha'. .. code-block:: none juju model-config -m <model> default-space=<space> .. note:: The juju model-default command can be used to affect all future models. A space is defined at the application level at deploy time (juju deploy). This becomes the application's de facto default space. That is, any scale out operation (juju add-unit) will inherit this value and any further integrations for the application will also use this value. .. note:: It has been reported that the default space at the model level does not work for LXD containers. This issue is being tracked in LP #1883164. Initial application unit ------------------------ When an application's initial unit is deployed, if the underlying subnet resides within a space then a binding must be formed by referencing a space. This is because the unit must be in a subnet in order to be assigned an IP address. The reference can be done explicitly at deploy time or implicitly via a model default. .. code-block:: none juju deploy --bind <space> <charm> Spaces as a constraint ---------------------- With the MAAS provider (backing cloud) the deployment of the initial unit can refer to a space as a Juju constraint. This simply ensures that the resulting machine has a network interface on a certain subnet(s). It is not used by the charm to implement any network functionality, as does a normal or extra binding: .. code-block:: none juju deploy --constraints spaces=<space> <charm> Such a constraint can be used in combination with a binding (using different space values naturally): .. code-block:: none juju deploy --constraints spaces=<space-1> --bind <space-2> <charm> LXD containers -------------- There is a subtle distinction between applying space constraints to LXD containers as opposed to bare metal or KVM-based MAAS nodes. For the latter types, a constraint represents a network criterion, whereas for dynamically-provisioned containers, a constraint acts as a request to add network connectivity. The underlying host however must be able to satisfy that request in terms of its own network connectivity. Subordinate applications ------------------------ A subordinate application always runs alongside a principal application and is only actually deployed when an integration is formed with its principal. Owing to this behaviour, the bindings of a subordinate application must be a subset of the bindings of the principal application. Multi-subnet spaces and routing ------------------------------- A binding (or extra binding) should be seen as a request to allocate traffic to certain subnets if possible, and not as a mechanism that alters or verifies routing at the L3 level. In the case of a multi-subnet space, this implies that network connectivity among those subnets must exist externally to Juju. Here are two key scenarios to watch out for when a multi-subnet space is desired: * multi-unit applications * any two integrated applications In each of the above scenarios, inter-subnet routing must be configured in advance to allow for the application units to reach one another. In other words, all subnets/VLANs within the same space are assumed to have unrestricted traffic. It should also be noted that an integration formed between two applications is not indicative of successful routing. Working with integrations and bindings -------------------------------------- This section will apply the concepts with an example scenario: that of deploying Vault and connecting it to the cloud database as in this section of the Deploy Guide. Here however, we will highlight how integrations and bindings are formed. The metadata.yaml file ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The pertinent contents of the metadata.yaml file for the vault and mysql-router charms will be shown. This consists of the following YAML keys: * provides * requires * extra-bindings This gives us: The vault charm: .. code-block:: yaml series: bionic applications: trilio-wlm: charm: ch:trilio-wlm Okay .. code-block:: yaml extra-bindings: access: external: provides: nrpe-external-master: interface: nrpe-external-master scope:container secrets: interface: vault-kv certificates: interface: tls-certificates requires: db: interface: pgsql shared-db: interface: mysql-shared etcd: interface: etcd ha: interface: hacluster scope: container lb-provider: interface: loadbalancer limit: 1 The mysql-router charm: .. code-block:: console provides: shared-db: interface: mysql-shared scope: container requires: juju-info: interface: juju-info scope: container db-router: interface: mysql-router Manual commands ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Some manual commands are included here that show how to achieve the objective. It is assumed that: * there are two spaces available to the MAAS cluster ('public-space' and 'access-space') * a default space is not configured at the model level * a cloud database is pre-existing (the mysql-innodb-cluster application) To deploy the vault application and set its default space to 'public-space': .. code-block:: none juju deploy --bind public-space --to lxd:3 --channel 1.8/stable vault To deploy the mysql-router application and integrate it with the cloud database: .. code-block:: none juju deploy --channel 8.0/stable mysql-router vault-mysql-router juju integrate vault-mysql-router:db-router mysql-innodb-cluster:db-router To integrate the shared-db endpoint of the vault application with the shared-db endpoint of the vault-mysql-router application: .. code-block:: none juju integrate vault-mysql-router:shared-db vault:shared-db The shared-db endpoint traffic will now be confined to space 'public-space'. .. note:: Regardless of the common name of the two endpoints, it is technically the common interface name of mysql-shared that makes the above integration possible. To form a binding between the access endpoint and the 'access-space' space: .. code-block:: none juju bind vault access=access-space An integration is not necessary for the access endpoint due to it being associated with an extra binding. The bundle method ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The entire example deployment can be expressed in the following bundle file, say vault-to-database.yaml: .. code-block:: console machines: '3': applications: vault-mysql-router: charm: ch:mysql-router channel: 8.0/stable vault: charm: ch:vault channel: 1.8/stable num_units: 1 bindings: "": public-space access: access-space to: - lxd:3 relations: - - vault-mysql-router:db-router - mysql-innodb-cluster:db-router - - vault:shared-db - vault-mysql-router:shared-db The pair of double quotation marks denotes the default space for an application. To deploy: .. code-block:: none juju deploy ./vault-to-database.yaml

commit_message:
Restore quincy/edge channel in test bundles

The bundles were temporarily switched to use quincy/stable
to work around the related bug. This changes ensures
the channels are restored to quincy/edge.

Change-Id: I04e2796779640e5004f2e1679ee9a3113eab1bb8
Related-Bug: #1995086

commit_message:
Allow nebulous-project-config-core to submit changes

This is necessary to make the nebulous tenant self-sustaining by
allowing this group to merge untested/failing changes in case of
a serious misconfiguration not solvable otherwise.

Change-Id: Ieb5c83b3e94b16f4d9c1602f7a1d8da27d9e5543

commit_message:
Expose ovn lb on provider network if tenant network is disabled

The logic to expose the ovn lb on the provider network was
relying on the information about the tenant networks connected to
the cr-lrp, that is only filled in when tenant networks are also
exposed. This patch is changing that so that this loadbalancers
are exposed even if the tenant networks are not.

Change-Id: I297af3b87b9683724977c279d0f5f5157abe2672

commit_message:
ovs: fix regression when vlan mapping is not already registered

Bug introduced by Ic3c147136549b17aea0fe78e930a41a5b33ab9d8, when a
VLAN mapping is not registered during a call to
update_network_segement, the function should return None.

Closes-Bug: #2009215
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@industrialdiscipline.com>
Change-Id: I91f8e8bd18d9956216e5715c658dfb408a2cbf07
(cherry picked from commit cf96bd8bdf9751c54ba8d47569e4a1269fc61e9e)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I487f7bb126b782925a61b9eb144214f78baf8cc0

commit_message:
Drop empty elements from constraint/requirement files

We should filter out empty elements from lists that are provided as
input to the role, to ensure idempotence of build constraints and
requirements file as a result.

Additionally to that we should ensure to control jinja whitespaces
not to add extra new lines to the end of files.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/872896
Change-Id: Ide47712f775c91d90b749bc8e4d8f87c5bd658f2
Closes-Bug: #2004546
(cherry picked from commit 2a25337b9844b4b8a90420e864ee38e8168ce586)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-09 20:39:36.000000000', 'files': ['metalsmith/test/test_metalsmith_instances.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith/commit/073bfb1978f37e073b86b786ce69cda8c2a58528', 'message': "test_provision: don't assert provision_node call order

provision_node is called from thread pool workers so the call order is
not deterministic. This causes py38 job failures sometimes.

commit_message:
test_provision: don't assert provision_node call order

provision_node is called from thread pool workers so the call order is
not deterministic. This causes py38 job failures sometimes.

This change asserts that the expected calls are occuring, but not
their order.

Change-Id: Id9f870e35dc9c92f0456d85c087514fb53053b76
(cherry picked from commit 43eec5a109888791ea395b2bab201106cbcdfff1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/metalsmith refs/changes/42/877042/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
test_provision: don't assert provision_node call order

provision_node is called from thread pool workers so the call order is
not deterministic. This causes py38 job failures sometimes.

This change asserts that the expected calls are occuring, but not
their order.

Change-Id: Id9f870e35dc9c92f0456d85c087514fb53053b76
(cherry picked from commit 43eec5a109888791ea395b2bab201106cbcdfff1)

commit_message:
Use the SDK for server show

Use the SDK for the server show command. This change modifies a helper
function that is used by server show as well as other commands that
print information about an individual server. The helper still uses
novaclient APIs when additional OpenStack requests are needed since some
of its callers are still using the nova client.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/864340
Change-Id: Ic253184ee5f911ec2052419d328260dc4664b273

added_lines: compute_client = self.app.client_manager.sdk_connection.compute # Find by name or ID, then get the full details of the server server = compute_client.find_server( parsed_args.server, ignore_missing=False) server = compute_client.get_server(server) data = compute_client.get_server_diagnostics(server) if not sdk_utils.supports_microversion(compute_client, '2.78'): topology = server.fetch_topology(compute_client) # TODO(dannosliwcd): Replace with SDK client after all callers of # _prep_server_detail() are using the SDK. self.app.client_manager.compute, self.app.client_manager.image, server,
deleted_lines: compute_client = self.app.client_manager.compute server = utils.find_resource( compute_client.servers, parsed_args.server) (resp, data) = server.diagnostics() if not resp.status_code == 200: self.app.stderr.write(_( "Error retrieving diagnostics data\n" )) return ({}, {}) if compute_client.api_version < api_versions.APIVersion('2.78'): topology = server.topology() compute_client, self.app.client_manager.image, server,

commit_message:
Fix unit tests with python-novaclient 18.3.0

python-novaclient 18.3.0 replaced usage of kwargs by explicit arguments
and that broke some assertions of arguments.

story: 2010638
task: 47613
Change-Id: I039d1e672611b7b523ce61df072c60d161851eed
(cherry picked from commit 513dfd116e5177cb43a0fb78471ad1992f16210d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/22/876922/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(tkajinam): python-novaclient 18.3.0 removed usage of args/kwargs # and now all arguments are defined. To make the test # independent from the underlying inteface as much as # possible we inspect kwargs and check what we intend # to define in Heat's logic. mock_rebuild.assert_called_once() self.assertEqual((return_server, '2'), mock_rebuild.call_args.args) if 'REBUILD' == policy: self.assertLessEqual( { 'password': password, 'preserve_ephemeral': False, 'meta': {}, 'files': {} }.items(), mock_rebuild.call_args.kwargs.items() ) else: self.assertLessEqual( { 'password': password, 'preserve_ephemeral': True, 'meta': {}, 'files': {} }.items(), mock_rebuild.call_args.kwargs.items() ) # NOTE(tkajinam): python-novaclient 18.3.0 removed usage of args/kwargs # and now all arguments are defined. To make the test # independent from the underlying inteface as much as # possible we inspect kwargs and check what we intend # to define in Heat's logic. mock_rebuild.assert_called_once() self.assertEqual((return_server, '2'), mock_rebuild.call_args.args) self.assertLessEqual( { 'password': None, 'preserve_ephemeral': False, 'meta': {}, 'files': {} }.items(), mock_rebuild.call_args.kwargs.items() )
deleted_lines: if 'REBUILD' == policy: mock_rebuild.assert_called_once_with( return_server, '2', password=password, preserve_ephemeral=False, meta={}, files={}) else: mock_rebuild.assert_called_once_with( return_server, '2', password=password, preserve_ephemeral=True, meta={}, files={}) mock_rebuild.assert_called_once_with( return_server, '2', password=None, preserve_ephemeral=False, meta={}, files={})

Migrate ceph-rbd-mirror to charmhub - octopus

This is the stable/octopus branch of ceph-rbd-mirror. It tests
against bionic-train (nautilus) and focal-ussuri (octopus).

Run tox -e build'; exit 1; fi" tox --version tox -e func-target {posargs}

commit_message:
Pin tox to < 4.0.0

Tox 4.0.0 was recently released and it has several breaking changes.
We pin to < 4.0.0 here. We are planning to move forward only on the
master charm branches.

Tox is also pinned to < 4.0.0 for stable branches in upstream
openstack-zuul-jobs as well as in zosci-config. However, the
requires= section in the charm's tox.ini file ends up installing
tox>4, wiping out the zuul-pinned tox<4 that was already installed
installed. This patch fixes that.

Related-Bug: #2002788
Change-Id: I92bc88c044cc1dd1ca65ae59273d8ff9c20f9812
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceph-osd refs/changes/24/871324/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix share network create command with the AZ option
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-04-08 11:01:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient/commit/dc3399f8d02823d341e386c54731afb6a9b0281f', 'message': "	refactor a code to add support for create a share network bug in the cli

	Previously, share network create was taking one argument, by adding cli support
	it is taking both arguments now and shared network is created successfully.
	The 'find_resource()' method there calls out to the AvailabilityZoneManager
	however manager doesnot support getting one resource by its name.
	So 'find_resource()' method was dropped and 'availability_zone' value was set to
       'parsed_args.availability_zone' to solve the problem.

	Closes-Bug: 1962288

Change-Id: I3ec926122eed932caebcb31b9afd0f811f1f3c8e

commit_message:
Fix share network create command with the AZ option

Previously, "share network create" command was trying to look up
the availability-zone provided by the user. However, this is not supported
by the AvailabilityZoneManager.

Drop the AZ lookup if the option is used and pass the user provided value
to the API.

Closes-Bug: 1962288
Change-Id: I3ec926122eed932caebcb31b9afd0f811f1f3c8e

subject: Limit CaptureRegion sizes in format_inspector for VMDK and VHDX
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-02-07 16:49:15.000000000', 'files': ['glance/tests/unit/common/test_format_inspector.py', 'glance/common/format_inspector.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/06a18202ab52c64803f044b8f848ed1c160905d2', 'message': 'Limit CaptureRegion sizes in format_inspector for VMDK and VHDX

VMDK:
When parsing a VMDK file to calculate its size, the format_inspector
determines the location of the Descriptor section by reading two
uint64 from the headers of the file and uses them to create the
descriptor CaptureRegion.

It would be possible to craft a VMDK file that commands the
format_inspector to create a very big CaptureRegion, thus exhausting
resources on the glance-api process.

This patch binds the beginning of the descriptor to 0x200 and limits
the size of the CaptureRegion to 1MB, similar to how the VMDK
descriptor is parsed by qemu.

VHDX:
It is a bit more involved, but similar: when looking for the
VIRTUAL_DISK_SIZE metadata, the format_inspector was creating an
unbounded CaptureRegion.

In the same way as it seems to be done in Qemu, we now limit the upper
bound of this CaptureRegion.

Closes-Bug: #2006490
Change-Id: I3ec5a33df20e1cfb6673f4ff1c7c91aacd065532
(cherry picked from commit d4d33ee30f303f783c0640cd72acb31b313e1164)
'}]
commit_message:
Limit CaptureRegion sizes in format_inspector for VMDK and VHDX

VMDK:
When parsing a VMDK file to calculate its size, the format_inspector
determines the location of the Descriptor section by reading two
uint64 from the headers of the file and uses them to create the
descriptor CaptureRegion.

It would be possible to craft a VMDK file that commands the
format_inspector to create a very big CaptureRegion, thus exhausting
resources on the glance-api process.

This patch binds the beginning of the descriptor to 0x200 and limits
the size of the CaptureRegion to 1MB, similar to how the VMDK
descriptor is parsed by qemu.

VHDX:
It is a bit more involved, but similar: when looking for the
VIRTUAL_DISK_SIZE metadata, the format_inspector was creating an
unbounded CaptureRegion.

In the same way as it seems to be done in Qemu, we now limit the upper
bound of this CaptureRegion.

Closes-Bug: #2006490
Change-Id: I3ec5a33df20e1cfb6673f4ff1c7c91aacd065532
(cherry picked from commit d4d33ee30f303f783c0640cd72acb31b313e1164)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/90/872990/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: VHDX_METADATA_TABLE_MAX_SIZE = 32 * 2048 # From qemu item_length = min(item_length, self.VHDX_METADATA_TABLE_MAX_SIZE) # The beginning and max size of the descriptor is also hardcoded in Qemu # at 0x200 and 1MB - 1 DESC_OFFSET = 0x200 DESC_MAX_SIZE = (1 << 20) - 1 # Since we parse both desc_sec and desc_num (the location of the # VMDK's descriptor, expressed in 512 bytes sectors) we enforce a # check on the bounds to create a reasonable CaptureRegion. This # is similar to how it's done in qemu. desc_offset = desc_sec * 512 desc_size = min(desc_num * 512, self.DESC_MAX_SIZE) if desc_offset != self.DESC_OFFSET: raise ImageFormatError("Wrong descriptor location") desc_offset, desc_size))

commit_message:
Add tasks to configure swap file/partion

For nova-compute, swap must be enabled by default.

Port existing t-h-t extraconfigs for swap by file or partition.

Add the swap config task into deploy-tripleo-os-install.yml.

Add CAP_SYS_ADMIN for molecule podman driver config so that it could
execute the swapon command under test.

Change-Id: I2b0e79ffc9cbc114d3f22609f5aee10a3c516b0a
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. - name: Configure swap file become: true when: - not tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition|bool shell: | #!/bin/bash set -eu if [ ! -f {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} ]; then dd if=/dev/zero of={{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} count={{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_size_megabytes }} bs=1M chmod 0600 {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} mkswap {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} swapon {{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} if ! grep -qE "{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }}\b" /etc/fstab; then echo "{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_path }} swap swap defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab fi fi - name: Configure swap partiion become: true when: - tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition|bool shell: | #!/bin/bash set -eu changed=1 if [ -e "/dev/disk/by-label/{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition_label }}" ]; then swap_partition=$(realpath /dev/disk/by-label/{{ tripleo_nova_compute_swap_partition_label }}) if ! grep -qE "${swap_partition}\b" /etc/fstab; then echo "$swap_partition swap swap defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab changed=0 fi else for item in $(lsblk -f --output FSTYPE,UUID | awk '/swap/ {print $2}'); do if ! grep -qe "${item}" /etc/fstab; then echo -e "UUID=${item} swap swap defaults 0 0" >> /etc/fstab changed=0 fi done fi if [ $changed -eq 0 ]; then swapon -a fi

commit_message:
Use /run/nova/ for nova-comp delay script

Nova have no permissions to write into /run.
Use /run/nova instead, and ensure its creation by the systemd tmpfiles

Change-Id: I010f6b8190b0897917d9fb507f626d50c5564a28
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Disable B113 rule of bandit

The new release of bandit just came out which introduced the new rule,
with which unfortunately heat is not compliant now.

This disables the rule temporally so that we can avoid adapting our
stable branches to new lint rules by backporting this.

Change-Id: I4a27049d40760ad8da6fda24e1195e26ef9c6c17

commit_message:
Update replica state before promote.

During promote of replica, retrieve replica state from backend before
promotion. In case DB state is in-sync, but backend reports out-sync,
abort promotion.

Closes-bug: #1989126
Change-Id: I60cfaeef18cc9040d3d25c62490baddbf9767539
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/39/856539/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - During promotion of replica, replica state is retrieved from DB and it is updated by periodic task for every 5 minute. User try to promote replica looking at DB state, while actual state in backend might be different. Fix this by fetching latest replica state from backend before promotion.

commit_message:
Ceph: Disable IPv4 when IPv6 should be used

... instead of enabling both of IPv4 and IPv6. This allows us to detect
any configurations relying on IPv4.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-ceph/+/876750
Change-Id: Ic5e428013d079d7bf4f759cd9af1b52b36b2cfb2

commit_message:
Check whether live_migration_permit_post_copy=True

When live_migration_permit_post_copy is set to true, then the live
migration does not work for paused instances (see linked bug).

This patch introduces new option
[compute-feature-enabled].live_migration_permit_post_copy. When this
option is set to true then tests that perform live migration of paused
instances are skipped.

Related-Bug: #1671011
Change-Id: I8b69303000be8e089912aa442d90f7951cf30489
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/66/876966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make the network_data search more inclusive

It's possible to also use --networks-file instead of
-n in the overcloud deploy command. This change adds
a secondary search string to the awk command to ensure
we capture the file regardless of which argument has
been used in the overcloud deploy script.

Resolves: rhbz#2064354
Change-Id: I13137b558b8a55f22462a2c6a26cdb8616fdc64e

commit_message:
Support tunables for announce_self sending

We already added support from the option to enable this feature[1].
This makes some tunables of the feature so that operators can customize
some options using the native interfaces.

[1] 4a77e0a5b9b46ff33e86a7e117a021dd15b7400e

Change-Id: I68533b2166e93efcc73227619181fc95809d12d0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/17/876817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*qemu_monitor_announce_self_count*] # (Optional) The total number of times to send the announce_self command to # the QEMU monitor when enable_qemu_monitor_announce_self is enabled. # Defaults to $facts['os_service_default'] # # [*qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval*] # (Optional) The number of seconds to wait before re-sending the announce_self # command to the QEMU monitor. # Defaults to $facts['os_service_default'] # $qemu_monitor_announce_self_count = $facts['os_service_default'], $qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval = $facts['os_service_default'], 'workarounds/qemu_monitor_announce_self_count': value => $qemu_monitor_announce_self_count; 'workarounds/qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval': value => $qemu_monitor_announce_self_interval;

commit_message:
Add support for [ovs] of_listen_address/port

... so that we can use IPv6 address instead of the default IPv4 local
address.

Change-Id: I5baa7e7dfac33e267790525dc1e8b963c3166cc0

commit_message:
Add Axel as release liaison

Axel stepped up as DPTL to mistral team. Renat is mostly inactive, so
let's replace him with Axel. Adding Axel's email address that is used
in gerrit, so that our PTL-Approved flag can be triggered by his
reviews.

Change-Id: I109a254ab8b0d602b6ac53e780378a2477915b25

commit_message:
Neutron: Enable metering agent only when Telemetry is enabled

The metering-agent service is an optional service to gather metrics in
Telemetry(ceilometer + gnocchi), thus is usually disabled if Telemetry
is disabled.

This change disables the service in the scenarios without Telemetry so
that we can validate deployments without this optional service.

Change-Id: I6f1bb575b891318ac83e26450d7b0699a1911b66

commit_message:
Horizon: Completely switch to PyMemcache backend

We replaced[1] the deprecated MemcachedCache backend in CentOS[1] but
has been using the deprecated backend in Ubuntu because of the old
package in Ubuntu Focal.

Now we use Ubuntu Jammy which provides python3-pymemcache 3.5.0, so can
use PyMemcacheCache backend

[1] a0bfa42751c35358f135e791f90af97e6d92cf32

Change-Id: I609b8a7da6668185294d50b92344fbfa1d3f9db2

commit_message:
Add further workaround features for qemu_monitor_announce_self

In some cases on Arista VXLAN fabrics, VMs are inaccessible via network
after live migration, despite garps being observed on the fabric itself.

This patch builds on the feature
``[workarounds]/enable_qemu_monitor_announce_self`` feature as reported
in `bug 1815989 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1815989>`

This patch adds the ability to config the number of times the QEMU
announce_self monitor command is called, and add a new configuration option to
specify a delay between calling the announce_self command multiple times,
as in some cases, multiple announce_self monitor commands are required for
the fabric to honor the garp packets and the VM to become accessible via
the network after live migration.

Closes-Bug: #1996995
Change-Id: I2f5bf7c9de621bb1dc7fae5b3374629a4fcc1f46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/24/867324/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('enable_qemu_monitor_announce_max_retries', default=3, min=0, help=""" The number of times to re-send the announce_self command to the QEMU monitor, in addition to the first attempt. If max_retries is set to 3, there will be a total of four calls to the QEMU announce_self command. Related options: * :oslo.config:option:`DEFAULT.compute_driver` (libvirt) """), cfg.IntOpt('enable_qemu_monitor_announce_retry_interval', default=1, min=0, help=""" The number of seconds to wait before re-sending the announce_self command to the QEMU monitor. Related options: * :oslo.config:option:`DEFAULT.compute_driver` (libvirt) """),

commit_message:
Pin nettle-3.8-3 on ubi9 only

This patch fixes the workaround proposed in [1] to install
nettle-3.8-3 only on ubi9 containers.
Since we are backporting this fix to stable/wallaby, we need
to guarantee that doesn't break ubi8 containers.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-common/+/869104

Change-Id: I039ca97773699f6f744e83172dd6664ace0d8d60

This workaround can be reverted once ubi9.2 is released, which # should contain a newer version of gnutls with fixes to run under FIPS mode. # See: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2154924 and # https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1984237 - run: >- if [ '{{ tcib_release }}' == '9' ];then dnf -y install nettle-3.8-3.el9; fi

subject: Shrinking: add states and biggest_candidate root recon metrics
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2022-12-02 05:11:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/b232f5ffd219f353907bff5934a019cab4cbd336', 'message': "Add some shard health metrics

This patch adds some new shard related metrics that will extend our
current shard health metrics:

  1. shard_list.visited_shards.<num>:
    This metric is fired down in the container controller in the
    proxy and basically counts the number of shards it had to talk
    to to build a listing response [1]
    Note however, shards it visits may then recurse into sub-shards,
    these aren't tracked. Just the number of shards it walked through
    at the upper level.

    The metric is fires off is based on now many it had to visit. In a
    healthy distributed root container, each shard should be quite
    large, with a 10,000 list limit, this number should almost always be
    a 1 or 2 to build a listing response. If it has to visit many more
    shards to build up the 10,000 max limit then this is an indication
    of alot of small shards that may need to be shrunk.

  2. audit_root.range_count.<n-1>000_<n>000:
    This metric is fired from audit_root_container in the sharder. It
    will track the number of shard ranges are in a root, and fire of a
    metric based on which thousand'th the container is in.
    Anything < 1000 will be in:

       audit_root.range_count.0000_1000

    Something that has more then 7000 shard ranges but less the 8k:

      audit_root.range_count.7000_8000

    I suspect most container will be in the 0000_1000, so this count
    should be high. But we'd start seeing how many large containers in
    the cluster.
    Note however, this will be fired from a sharder as it visits a root
    container, so if your aggregating, you might want to divide by the
    container replica count.

With these two metrics, we should get a better pickure of the overall
distribution and size health of shards in a cluster.

Another reason for this patch, is so when we do get shrinking happening,
we should see improvements via these metrics.

Change-Id: Ie39e83fe1d20518fdc68c24436c6b1e278e5690a

  2. audit_root.range_count.<n-1>000_<n>000:
    This metric is fired from audit_root_container in the sharder. It

    Anything < 1000 will be in:

       audit_root.range_count.0000_1000

    Something that has more then 7000 shard ranges but less the 8k:

      audit_root.range_count.7000_8000

    Note however, this will be fired from a sharder as it visits a root

With these two metrics, we should get a better pickure of the overall

Change-Id: Ie39e83fe1d20518fdc68c24436c6b1e278e5690a

commit_message:
Shrinking: add states and biggest_candidate root recon metrics

When looking at shrinking candidates it might be nice to know how many
active ranges there are to compare against the number of compactable
ranges. Further when tracking the progress of cleaving (cleaving or
shrinking) knowing how many ranges are in the shrinking state would also
be nice to track.

This patch adds shrinking to the state_count used by the
sharding_inprogress code, but also includes the state_count in the
shrinking candidates, shrinking candidates are root containers and
knowing how many ranges are in what state is interesting.

Something else we're missing is the ability to track the largest roots
in the cluster. When auditing a root container, this patch also tracks
the top x biggest (active shard count) root containers and reports them
in the recon dump as the biggest_candidates.

Change-Id: Ie39e83fe1d20518fdc68c24436c6b1e278e5690a

commit_message:
Check VMDK subformat against an allowed list

Also add a more general check to convert_image that the image format
reported by qemu-img matches what the caller says it is.

Change-Id: I3c60ee4c0795aadf03108ed9b5a46ecd116894af
Partial-bug: #1996188
(cherry picked from commit 930fc93e9fda82a4aa4568ae149c3c80af7379d0)

Conflicts:
  cinder/image/image_utils.py
   - changed type annotations to use implicit Optional to be
     consistent with cinder yoga mypy usage
   - removed refs to image_conversion_disable in tests
(cherry picked from commit 2ae5d53526e2b224d81b3259140c59aba97d72c3)
(cherry picked from commit e96415409daa158cc503c1adec1ca1ca4f940082)
Conflicts:

   - removed type annotations
   - restored wallaby-era fetch_verify_image() function signature
(cherry picked from commit be11d54ac420e0ebc0da6917d7ffc3af59b40f24)

Additions:

   - added a test for ^^
(cherry picked from commit 17565262dafb5beeaec8e9e249e760fc64f3df93)

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/31/871631/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | This release introduces a new configuration option, ``vmdk_allowed_types``, that specifies the list of VMDK image subformats that Cinder will allow. The default setting allows only the 'streamOptimized' and 'monolithicSparse' subformats, which do not use named extents. security: - | This release introduces a new configuration option, ``vmdk_allowed_types``, that specifies the list of VMDK image subformats that Cinder will allow in order to prevent exposure of host information by modifying the named extents in a VMDK image. The default setting allows only the 'streamOptimized' and 'monolithicSparse' subformats, which do not use named extents. - | As part of the fix for `Bug #1996188 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1996188>`_, cinder is now more strict in checking that the ``disk_format`` recorded for an image (as revealed by the Image Service API image-show response) matches what cinder detects when it downloads the image. Thus, some requests to create a volume from a source image that had previously succeeded may fail with an ``ImageUnacceptable`` error. fixes: - | `Bug #1996188 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1996188>`_: Fixed issue where a VMDK image file whose createType allowed named extents could expose host information. This change introduces a new configuration option, ``vmdk_allowed_types``, that specifies the list of VMDK image subformats that Cinder will allow. The default setting allows only the 'streamOptimized' and 'monolithicSparse' subformats.

subject: Add the main NebulOuS repos
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-02 10:15:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/179c65b28752271f9253824412981c929e15a02d', 'message': "Add the main NebulOuS repo

The NebulOuS project aims to deliver a Meta Operating System and
Fog Brokerage Platform for transient cloud continuum ecosystems. [1]

This patch follows the Project Creator's Guide to create a new
project in OpenDev's collaboratory.

commit_message:
Add the main NebulOuS repos

The NebulOuS project aims to deliver a Meta Operating System and
Fog Brokerage Platform for transient cloud continuum ecosystems. [1]

This patch follows the Project Creator's Guide to create a new
project in OpenDev's collaboratory.

It also creates the project-config repo in preparation for the creation
of a new Zuul tenant: nebulous.

[1] https://www.nebulouscloud.eu/

Change-Id: I369177cd43f92f02a73011b46545210015d5112a

commit_message:
Backport openstack_testing from Yoga

At the moment we're facing issues with tempest failing to install
all required plugins due to not matching constraints with requirements

In order to prevent that we used to fix plugin versions directly in the
tempest role in an ad-hoc manner. However, it's better to use
correct and working versions of plugins for the branch, so SHAs were
backported from Y which should work correctly.

Also according to no objections raised during the meeting [1], we're
disabling upgrade jobs from branches that are currently in EM, since
we don't need to block current development due to EM failures.

[1] https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-ansible/%23openstack-ansible.2023-03-07.log.html#t2023-03-07T15:06:59

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server/+/875782
Change-Id: I11f5326724ac1af00166f2d6d86cd3427470fea0

Default is the same as html_title. #html_short_title = None # The name of an image file (relative to this directory) to place at the top # of the sidebar. #html_logo = None # The name of an image file (within the static path) to use as favicon of the # docs. This file should be a Windows icon file (.ico) being 16x16 or 32x32 # pixels large. #html_favicon = None # Add any paths that contain custom static files (such as style sheets) here, # relative to this directory. They are copied after the builtin static files, # so a file named "default.css" will overwrite the builtin "default.css". html_static_path = ['_static'] # Add any extra paths that contain custom files (such as robots.txt or # .htaccess) here, relative to this directory. These files are copied # directly to the root of the documentation. #html_extra_path = [] # If not '', a 'Last updated on:' timestamp is inserted at every page bottom, # using the given strftime format. # If true, SmartyPants will be used to convert quotes and dashes to # typographically correct entities. #html_use_smartypants = True # Custom sidebar templates, maps document names to template names. #html_sidebars = {} # Additional templates that should be rendered to pages, maps page names to # template names. #html_additional_pages = {} # If false, no module index is generated. #html_domain_indices = True # If false, no index is generated. #html_use_index = True # If true, the index is split into individual pages for each letter. #html_split_index = False # If true, links to the reST sources are added to the pages. #html_show_sourcelink = True # If true, "Created using Sphinx" is shown in the HTML footer. commit_message:
Add charms-stable-maint group for charms projects

We've decided to add a new group to help manage stable maintenance of
the stable branches in the charms group of projects.  Note that
charms-ceph and charms-vault are part of the charms set of projects but
already have slightly different groups of maintainers.

Change-Id: Ibcb89c87a15d72d05b6a9f599aede3a7b60f4df6

commit_message:
slo_manifest_hook follow-up

Two big things:

* Since the data_for_storage we pass to the slo_manifest_hook is
  intentionally mutable, make sure the hook doesn't do anything *too*
  crazy with it.

* If the hook changed the large object's size (by adding or removing
  segments, for example), make sure that is reflected in the final
  manifest metadata.

Change-Id: I71222801023ce63b07b94374f2e340db5a982acd
Related-Change: I198c5196e0221a72b14597a06e5ce3c4b2bbf436

added_lines: def test_handle_multipart_put_with_faulty_callback(self): def bad_inserter(manifest): manifest[:] = [1, {}, {"data": "x", "name": "y"}] good_data = json.dumps([ {'path': '/checktest/a_1'}, {'path': '/checktest/b_2'}]) req = Request.blank( '/v1/AUTH_test/checktest/man_3?multipart-manifest=put', environ={'REQUEST_METHOD': 'PUT', 'swift.callback.slo_manifest_hook': bad_inserter}, body=good_data) status, headers, body = self.call_slo(req) self.assertEqual([ ('HEAD', '/v1/AUTH_test/checktest/a_1'), ('HEAD', '/v1/AUTH_test/checktest/b_2'), # No PUT! ], sorted(self.app.calls)) # Client didn't have any say in what went wrong, so no useful error self.assertEqual(status, '500 Internal Error') self.assertEqual(body.split('\n'), [ 'Response Body: Internal Error', 'The server has either erred or is incapable ' 'of performing the requested operation.', 'Response Status: 500 Internal Error', 'Errors:', '', ]) # but it'll show up in logs self.assertEqual(self.slo.logger.get_lines_for_level('error'), [ "Invalid manifest after calling slo_manifest_hook: " "[1, {}, {'data': 'x', 'name': 'y'}]", 'Item 0: expected a dict, got 1', "Item 1: missing required keys ['name', 'bytes', 'hash'] in " "segment dict {}", 'Item 2: found both "name" and "data" in segment dict: ' '{\'data\': \'x\', \'name\': \'y\'}', ])

commit_message:
Periodically update Puppetfile_unit

This updates the script to automatically update puppet constraints so
that Puppetfile_unit is updated as well as Puppetfile. We introduced
this separate file[1] a while ago but have not been updated it
properly. Updating it periodically helps us catch up with any update
in the dependent modules more timely.

[1] 047ea125ddefa8151d6592d4772560a1b23a13dc

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/875301
Change-Id: I4d89a2985781f14d9ff7f76f412f0b8ccc4c6ddb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/02/875302/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # header echo -e "# Auto-generated Puppetfile for Puppet OpenStack project\n" > $DIR/Puppetfile_unit # OpenStack Modules echo "## OpenStack modules" >> $DIR/Puppetfile for p in $(cat openstack_modules.txt); do # hack for puppet-openstack-integration # where namespace is openstack_integration title=$(echo $p | sed 's/-/_/g') # TODO(emilien) we need to add support for stable branches cat >> $DIR/Puppetfile <<EOF mod '$title', :git => 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-$p', :ref => 'master' EOF done # Unit test Modules echo -e "## External modules" >> $DIR/Puppetfile_unit for e in $(cat unit_modules.txt); do namespace=$(echo $e | awk -F'/' '{print $1}' | cut -d "," -f 1) module=$(echo $e | awk -F'/' '{print $2}' | cut -d "," -f 1) title=$(echo $module | awk -F'/' '{print $1}' | cut -d "-" -f 2) pin=$(echo $e | grep "," | cut -d "," -f 2) if [ ! -z "$pin" ]; then git ls-remote --exit-code https://github.com/$namespace/$module $pin if (($? == 2)); then if ! git ls-remote --exit-code https://github.com/$namespace/$module | grep -q $pin; then echo "Wrong pin: $pin does not exist in $module module." exit 1 else tag=$pin fi else tag=$pin fi else git clone https://github.com/$namespace/$module modules/$module tag=$(cd modules/$module; git describe --tags $(git rev-list --tags --max-count=1)) rm -rf modules/$module fi cat >> $DIR/Puppetfile_unit <<EOF mod '$title', :git => 'https://github.com/$namespace/$module', :ref => '$tag' EOF done # for debug cat $DIR/Puppetfile_unit

commit_message:
Retire puppet-tacker - Step 1: End project Gating

This module has not attracted any interest and has been unmaintained.
We asked any feedback[1] about retiring this module but have received
no objections so far, so we can assume no one is really using it.

[1] https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2023-January/031894.html

Change-Id: I223a1e304eefc13d90b637087db3554bb6244142

subject: gerrit/acl : submit-requirements for deprecated NoOp function
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-01 05:16:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/ce15f35e87af3dddbfb1f130b0f875eb2f22d1a3', 'message': 'gerrit/acl : remove deprecated NoOp function

The submit functions are deprecated in Gerrit 3.7 and replaced with
submit-requirements.

This starts at the replacement with the NoOp function.  Since these
labels should never block submitting we replace it with a
submit-requirement of "is:true" which always passes.

This change itself should be a no-op.

Change-Id: Ic43f561174ebf30474b1b54be2bed02695cebedc
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2023-03-02 00:18:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/fad60cc7ccd655b91326d4724ddebec65df7d3e3', 'message': 'gerrit/acl : remove deprecated NoOp function

The submit functions are deprecated in Gerrit 3.7 and replaced with
submit-requirements.

This starts at the replacement with the NoOp function.  Since these
labels should never block submitting we replace it with a
submit-requirement of "is:true" which always passes.

This change itself should be a no-op.

Change-Id: Ic43f561174ebf30474b1b54be2bed02695cebedc
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2023-03-02 05:48:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/111683726ed4661b268f7e27b4d32f849eda3569', 'message': 'gerrit/acl : submit-requirements for deprecated NoOp function

The submit functions are deprecated in Gerrit 3.7 and replaced with
submit-requirements.

This starts at the replacement with ACL's currently using the NoOp
function.  Labels currently must have a function associated with them,
so the NoOp function is retained.

However, to future-proof ourselves and to be consistent across all the
ACL files, we add an explicit submit-requirement for the label.  Since
these labels should never block submitting we use only a
submit-requirement of "is:true" which always passes.

This change itself should be a no-op.

Change-Id: Ic43f561174ebf30474b1b54be2bed02695cebedc
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2023-03-03 03:42:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/593fa4f543bb47c1c13f8bf575fe557973ef619b', 'message': 'gerrit/acl : submit-requirements for deprecated NoOp function

The submit functions are deprecated in Gerrit 3.7 and replaced with
submit-requirements.

This starts at the replacement with ACL's currently using the NoOp
function.  Labels currently must have a function associated with them,
so the NoOp function is retained.

However, to future-proof ourselves and to be consistent across all the
ACL files, we add an explicit submit-requirement for the label.  Since
these labels should never block submitting we use only a
submit-requirement of "is:true" which always passes.

This change itself should be a no-op.

Change-Id: Ic43f561174ebf30474b1b54be2bed02695cebedc
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2023-03-07 22:21:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/45a00c2f64acfe652f5b574607c7b93b9f2b280e', 'message': 'gerrit/acl : submit-requirements for deprecated NoOp function

submit-requirements.

This starts at the replacement with ACL's currently using the NoOp
function.

This implements the migrations steps encded with [1] upstream.  The
function is changed to NoBlock, and a "non-applicable"
submit-requirement of "applicableIf = is:false" and "submittableIf =
is:true" is added, with the same name as the label.

Since we are matching the upstream rules for idempotence -- a
submit-requirement with the same name as the label, we will avoid
future upgrades modifying our ACL's and getting them out of sync with
what we have in project-config.

From a user's point-of-view, this change itself should be a no-op.

[1] https://gerrit-review.googlesource.com/c/gerrit/+/339542

commit_message:
gerrit/acl : submit-requirements for deprecated NoOp function

The submit functions are deprecated in Gerrit 3.7 and replaced with
submit-requirements.

This starts at the replacement with ACL's currently using the NoOp
function.

This implements the migrations steps encded with [1] upstream.  The
function is changed to NoBlock, and a "non-applicable"
submit-requirement of "applicableIf = is:false" and "submittableIf =
is:true" is added, with the same name as the label.

Since we are matching the upstream rules for idempotence -- a
submit-requirement with the same name as the label, we will avoid
future upgrades modifying our ACL's and getting them out of sync with
what we have in project-config.

From a user's point-of-view, this change itself should be a no-op.

[1] https://gerrit-review.googlesource.com/c/gerrit/+/339542

Change-Id: Ic43f561174ebf30474b1b54be2bed02695cebedc

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I767e24e68eaf430cb9ba6439bf999fda2882153e

commit_message:
Do not use 'always' tag in inappropriate places

Using 'always' tag in combination with condition depending on
variables is not always a good idea because these variables may not be
defined at the moment.

Currently, rabbitmq_server role cannot be executed with tag limit,
because task containing 'always' tag has a condition operating on
variable(s) that are registered only when 'rabbitmq-config' tag is being
used.

Change-Id: I7ef7b3fed79933b4c8bbc39a63ca6db54532e10e

commit_message:
Fixes repositories files name in Rocky Linux 9

Distributions moved to lowercase names with RHEL 9 release.
This patch also removes previously created uppercase files.

Story: 2010637
Task: 47604
Change-Id: I8bf75ce44b9ec1fdd477fcddf2deebf2929d9fc1
(cherry picked from commit e0ff9a0283bd870df72ea7dec62d55ef0b8ed972)

commit_message:
WIP: Pin pylint tox env to python 3.9

Pylint on python 3.10 returns numerous spurious
no-member errors about the 'os' module.

This gets it to provide useful output instead.

Discussion here points to related issues:
https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/6535#issuecomment-1344826489

Change-Id: I85782e7312a263881b1bdcf820d717422fe6471a

commit_message:
Sync default policy rules

This patch updates default policy-in-code rules in horizon based on
nova/neutron/cinder RC deliverables. It doesn't update policy
rules for glance and keystone as I have found no changes in their
policy rules. Horizon needs to update default policy-in-code rules
for all backend services before releasing the horizon[1].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/contributor/policies/releasing.html#things-to-do-before-releasing

Change-Id: Iae50f131be3f7d1345b8b899b70da8301700428c

commit_message:
Removing helper functions providing Python < 3.3 compatibility

Functions used for deriving terminal width are no longer
necessary, as Python 3.3 introduced[0] built in solution.

Remaining helper function `utils.terminal_width` received docstring
explaining return parameters.

Method `_assign_max_widths` of the `TableFormatter` class was refactored
to no longer use the `stdout` argument. Uses of the method were adjusted accordingly.
Method now also has minimal docstring. Minor adjustment was made to inline comments
to more closely reflect functionality of the code.

[0]https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/os.html?highlight=get_terminal_size#os.get_terminal_size

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I2898f099227e8c97aef6492c60f2f99038aa1357
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cliff refs/changes/89/862689/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def terminal_width(): """Return terminal width in columns Uses `os.get_terminal_size` function :returns: terminal width :rtype: int or None """ try: return os.get_terminal_size().columns except OSError:
deleted_lines: import ctypesimport struct import sysdef terminal_width(stdout): if hasattr(os, 'get_terminal_size'): # python 3.3 onwards has built-in support for getting terminal size try: return os.get_terminal_size().columns except OSError: return None if sys.platform == 'win32': return _get_terminal_width_windows(stdout) else: return _get_terminal_width_ioctl(stdout) def _get_terminal_width_windows(stdout): STD_INPUT_HANDLE = -10 STD_OUTPUT_HANDLE = -11 STD_ERROR_HANDLE = -12 std_to_win_handle = { sys.stdin: STD_INPUT_HANDLE, sys.stdout: STD_OUTPUT_HANDLE, sys.stderr: STD_ERROR_HANDLE} std_handle = std_to_win_handle.get(stdout) if not std_handle: return None handle = ctypes.windll.kernel32.GetStdHandle(std_handle) csbi = ctypes.create_string_buffer(22) res = ctypes.windll.kernel32.GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo(handle, csbi) if res: (size_x, size_y, cur_pos_x, cur_pos_y, attr, left, top, right, bottom, max_size_x, max_size_y) = struct.unpack( "hhhhHhhhhhh", csbi.raw) return size_x def _get_terminal_width_ioctl(stdout): from fcntl import ioctl import termios try: # winsize structure has 4 unsigned short fields winsize = b'\0' * struct.calcsize('hhhh') try: winsize = ioctl(stdout, termios.TIOCGWINSZ, winsize) except IOError: return None except TypeError: # this is raised in unit tests as stdout is sometimes a StringIO return None winsize = struct.unpack('hhhh', winsize) columns = winsize[1] if not columns: return None return columns except IOError:

subject: Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-09 16:41:45.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/ba7dd3630e779447507e4e407a117d7a377a82d3', 'message': 'Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Iac3bf10942721195369d095149e1015fe0c9f8ef
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Iac3bf10942721195369d095149e1015fe0c9f8ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/99/876999/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
docker: Set ulimit nofile on EL9

Some latest RPM-based distributions, such as RHEL 9 and CentOS Stream 9, ship
a recent version of systemd that sets the default open file handle limit is
set to 1073741816.
That effects in various issues (like rabbitmq not working), including
ceph/other services in containers not working properly.
kolla-ansible has set that as a default ulimit for Kolla container images [1],
this patch sets that as a Docker Engine default (for container images
that don't have this overridden).

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/839715

Closes-Bug: #2008761

Change-Id: I48a8f18287aa3b017ce04d4b076d88989f927a56
(cherry picked from commit d985ef48b29f3cdbae9ff9f45f598d6a224545fd)
(cherry picked from commit b7afb0339e21372a18512f6934362857efbb54b0)

commit_message:
Backport openstack_testing from Yoga

At the moment we're facing issues with tempest failing to install
all required plugins due to not matching constraints with requirements

In order to prevent that we used to fix plugin versions directly in the
tempest role in an ad-hoc manner. However, it's better to use
correct and working versions of plugins for the branch, so SHAs were
backported from Y which should work correctly.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible-rabbitmq_server/+/876708
Change-Id: I11f5326724ac1af00166f2d6d86cd3427470fea0

subject: Removing 'horizon' from Ironic feature matrix
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-13 18:05:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/2cf73510c5fb13fe7e1429f7ad8d7113aa6a30a0', 'message': "Removing 'horizon' from Ironic feature matrix

Having horizon on the feature matrix of Ironic is not useful wrt feature testing
and is adding transient failures to Ironic's gate. This patch removes horizon
from devstack-gate's feature matrix, disabling it for all Ironic tests using
devstack-gate.

Change-Id: Ifdab1ade451b4d2543a520e38e54099f78cf8b26
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-08 19:13:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/4adcb3505086052b446601065e07e2370c6b17c0', 'message': "Removing 'horizon' from Ironic feature matrix

Having horizon on the feature matrix of Ironic is not useful wrt feature
testing and increases the surface of failure since bugs introduced in
Horizon may make Ironic gate fail. This patch removes horizon from
devstack-gate's feature matrix, disabling it for all Ironic tests using
devstack-gate.

Change-Id: Ifdab1ade451b4d2543a520e38e54099f78cf8b26
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-08-11 13:19:03.000000000', 'files': ['features.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/2409f03cb941d0c4bd24b84225ba0889c447c098', 'message': "Removing 'horizon' from Ironic feature matrix

Having horizon on the feature matrix of Ironic is not useful wrt feature
testing and increases the surface of failure since bugs introduced in
Horizon may make Ironic gate fail. This patch removes horizon from
devstack-gate's feature matrix, disabling it for all Ironic tests using
devstack-gate.

Change-Id: Ifdab1ade451b4d2543a520e38e54099f78cf8b26
"}]
commit_message:
Removing 'horizon' from Ironic feature matrix

Having horizon on the feature matrix of Ironic is not useful wrt feature
testing and increases the surface of failure since bugs introduced in
Horizon may make Ironic gate fail. This patch removes horizon from
devstack-gate's feature matrix, disabling it for all Ironic tests using
devstack-gate.

Change-Id: Ifdab1ade451b4d2543a520e38e54099f78cf8b26

commit_message:
spec: Clean Steps that are Available

This is a proposal for two API requests that can be used to find out
what all the available clean steps are for a node.

Change-Id: I0c69a294a6645b49ddb0b733cbd08b8f5074cb8f

commit_message:
Deprecate DHCP providers

The DHCP providers are deprecated and will be removed in Rocky release.

For those who using custom dhcp providers, custom network_interfaces
or custom deploy drivers. The network_interfaces should implement
`clean_dhcp` and `get_ip_addresses` methods. DHCP options are now set
when calling the following methods from network_interface and may be
passed as optional parameter `dhcp_opts`:

    * `add_provisioning_network`
    * `add_cleaning_network`
    * `configure_tenant_networks`

Closes-Bug: #1683777

Change-Id: I28960f499c0655f1e6c90044161bd88931912f79

in ironic-api.

commit_message:
Add hardware properties API to management interface

This spec proposes to extend driver management interface, add support
for "standardized" properties.

Related-bug: #1526475

Change-Id: I56030124beb7e2e8f94c2162e37cbb25fcb49220
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/12/209612/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== New driver interface for BIOS configuration =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/ironic-firmware-interface This spec presents a new driver interface for support BIOS and firmware settings configuration. Problem description =================== * There is no generic way in Ironic to do BIOS/FW configuration. * User should be able to get list of supported parameters and values from the driver. * Ironic should update capabilities of a node when corresponding parameters were changed. Proposed change =============== * New driver interface ``FirmwareInterface`` will be provided for BIOS/FW configuration. * New REST API endpoints will be created for setting and retrieving the BIOS/FW properties. * User gets/sets BIOS/FW configuration information for Ironic driver via REST API as JSON data. Example 1 of expose available parameters:: { 'bios': { [ { 'name': 'parameter1', 'description': 'setting foo', 'values': [0, 1, 2, 3], 'default': 0, 'capabilities': {'foo': {0: 'off', 3: 'on'}} 'reset_needed': True }, { 'name': 'parameter2', 'description': 'setting bar', 'values': ['stop', 'start'], 'apply_online': True }, ] }, 'controller1': { [ { 'name': 'parameter3', 'description': 'setting controller1', 'values': [8, 10], }, ] } In example above: * 'bios', 'controller1': names of configurable devices, mandatory. * 'name': name of parameter, mandatory. * 'description': human readable description, optional. * 'values': list of supported values, mandatory. * 'default': default value, optional. * 'capabilities': name and values of linked capabilities, optional. * 'apply_online': can be applied on the fly in any state of a node, optional, default is False. * 'reset_needed': node reset required after change, optional, default is True. Example 2 of expose current values:: { 'bios': { 'version': '1.09.2015E' 'settings': { parameter1': 2, parameter2': 'stop', }, }, 'controller1': { 'version': '1-0-567.k' 'settings': { 'parameter3': 10, }, } In example above: * 'version': firmware version string, mandatory, empty if unknown. Example 3 of setting new values:: { 'bios': { 'parameter2': 'start', }, 'controller1': { 'parameter3': 8, }, } Update BIOS/FW settings workflow: #. Driver does validate of user's parameters. #. If parameter(s) can be applied on the fly driver does update immediately. #. If parameter(s) can not be applied immediately driver saves them in node.driver_internal_info field with 'firmware_settings' key ('firmware_settings': {'bios': {'foo': 'bar'}}). #. Postponed parameters applied during zapping or cleaning procedure. #. Driver updates node capabilities if there are linked capabilities. Alternatives ------------ * Developers can use vendor passthru mechanism for BIOS/FW settings. * Users can change this settings manually. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None. REST API impact --------------- New REST API endpoints will be added: - To get BIOS/FW available parameters:: GET /v1/drivers/<driver>/firmware/properties Properties returned as example 1. - To set new parameters:: PUT /v1/nodes/NNNN/states/firmware with a BODY containing the JSON as example 3. - To get current parameters:: GET /v1/nodes/NNNN/states/firmware Parameters returned as example 2. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- New options should be added for getting/setting BIOS/FW parameters. RPC API impact -------------- New RPC API methods will be created: * ``get_firmware_properties`` - get parameters from a driver. * ``get_firmware_settings`` - get parameters for a node. * ``set_firmware_settings`` - set parameters for a node. Driver API impact ----------------- A new ``FirmwareInterface`` will be created. It will contain the following methods:: def validate(task): """Validates driver's parameters for BIOS/FW settings. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :raises: InvalidParameterValue, if configuration is invalid. :raises: MissingParameterValue, if configuration has some missing parameters. """ def get_firmware_properties(task): """Gets BIOS/FW properties defined by the driver. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :returns: A dictionary of properties. """ def get_firmware_settings(task): """Gets BIOS/FW settings for a node. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :returns: A dictionary of settings. """ def set_firmware_settings(task, settings): """Sets BIOS/FW settings for a node. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :param settings: A dictionary of settings. """ def reset_to_defaults(task, device): """Reset BIOS/FW settings for a node to factory defaults. :param task: TaskManager object containing the node. :param device: A name of device to reset. """ .. note:: - get_firmware_settings() method is optional, should raise NotImplementedError if not implemented. - reset_to_defaults() method can be used internally for cleaning/zapping, 'device' parameter is the name of device to reset like 'bios', 'controller1' in examples. Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Developers may implement this interface for drivers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: yuriyz Other contributors: vdrok Work Items ---------- * Create ``FirmwareInterface`` in base and for fake driver. * Create RPC API methods. * Create REST API endpoints. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be provided. References ========== http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-specs/specs/kilo-archive/drac-bios-mgmt.html

commit_message:
Documentation update for booting from volume

Boot from volume doc for Devstack is missing some of the configuration
details provided in the /admin/boot-from-volume.rst.

This patch updates /contributor/ironic-boot-from-volume.rst with creating
volume connector etc and links to /admin/boot-from-volume.rst.

commit_message:
Add missing error to log in do_node_deploy()

Helper function handle_failure() will make a log string
containing node uuid and error. But the handling process
of uploading configdrive to Swift missed the error when
calling this function. So this patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I4f020606c2dbb09140e8a639620f45fc9d8565ac

This change moves most of the common code for prepare, deploy,
tear_down and clean_up methods of agent and iscsi deploy
interfaces into the deploy_utils module.

Apart from that, iscsi deploy interface was triggering
boot.prepare_instance for nodes in ADOPTING state in the prepare method,
which in turn sets boot device. It should not be the case, as BMC of
ADOPTING nodes should not be accessed. Other things, like pxe config
switching, are necessary tho. On the other hand, agent deploy interface
was not calling boot.prepare_instance in prepare method for ADOPTING
nodes, so pxe configs did not get generated, but they should be, in case
of iscsi or netboot. This patch also fixes these inconsistencies.

Closes-Bug: #1735517

Change-Id: Iadd035cb59ccc1729f3ab3b7d61d667fedf8b6d6
'}]
commit_message:
Refactor deploy interface methods

This change moves most of the common code for prepare, deploy,
tear_down and clean_up methods of agent and iscsi deploy
interfaces into the deploy_utils module.

Apart from that, iscsi deploy interface was triggering
boot.prepare_instance for nodes in ADOPTING state in the prepare method,
which in turn sets boot device. It should not be the case, as BMC of
ADOPTING nodes should not be accessed. Other things, like pxe config
switching, are necessary tho. On the other hand, agent deploy interface
was not calling boot.prepare_instance in prepare method for ADOPTING
nodes, so pxe configs did not get generated, but they should be, in case
of iscsi or netboot. This patch also fixes these inconsistencies.

Closes-Bug: #1735517

Change-Id: Iadd035cb59ccc1729f3ab3b7d61d667fedf8b6d6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/33/524433/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # during takeover or ADOPTING nodes if boot_device and task.node.provision_state not in [ states.ACTIVE, states.ADOPTING]:
deleted_lines: # during takeover if boot_device and task.node.provision_state != states.ACTIVE:

commit_message:
Do not set ephemeral size based on driver

Stop relying on the driver to set ephemeral partition size and
use the value passed from the gate job.

Change-Id: I4df45636f52a1ed08368e122160cc79b6c423af2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/61/326061/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # agent driver doesn't support ephemeral volumes yet echo "IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK=0" >>"$localrc_file" echo "IRONIC_VM_EPHEMERAL_DISK=1" >>"$localrc_file"
