Change-Id: Id48457c43e38e19f781bfe11d1fb6eaeb9fdde6f
'}]
commit_message:
Fix tags usage for included tasks

With usage of include_tasks tags must be applied accordingly,
which was missing. That prevented running service load whenever
systemd-service tag was used.

Change-Id: Id48457c43e38e19f781bfe11d1fb6eaeb9fdde6f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ansible-role-systemd_service refs/changes/21/876321/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

['logging', 'router', 'security-group'] FILE_PATH = "/tmp/test_log.log" @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(LoggingTest, cls).resource_setup() def _is_log_data_set(self, log_lines, log_id): pattern = re.compile( r"^.*action=(ACCEPT|DROP).* log_resource_ids=\[.*%s.*" % log_id ) for line in log_lines: if pattern.match(line): return True return False def _check_log(self, log_id): with open(self.FILE_PATH) as f: log_data = f.readlines() return self._is_log_data_set(log_data, log_id) @decorators.idempotent_id('35d4b467-8dd9-4df3-b508-da737bfd96aa') def test_log(self): """This is a commit_message:
Test default network extension driver

Depends-On: I465ea140910af50d62ab281d26357861cf96952b
Change-Id: I6d5a23831d9df3f1c82e97c04bc4dc19ffd17296
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/46/542446/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @decorators.idempotent_id('40679dec-c4f4-4da6-bf8d-4137cd8655a9') @utils.requires_ext(extension="default-networks", service="network") def test_create_default_network(self): project_id = self.client.tenant_id # non-admin network = self.admin_client.create_network( **{"project_id": project_id, "is_default": True})['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, network['id']) self.assertIsNotNone(network['id']) self.assertTrue(network['is_default']) @decorators.idempotent_id('ba14f3eb-8cf6-4e74-a8b2-49c4c61582a4') @utils.requires_ext(extension="default-networks", service="network") def test_update_default_network(self): project_id = self.client.tenant_id # non-admin network = self.admin_client.create_network( **{"project_id": project_id})['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, network['id']) self.assertFalse(network.get('is_default', False)) updated_network = self.admin_client.update_network( network['id'], **{"is_default": True})['network'] self.assertTrue(updated_network['is_default']) @decorators.idempotent_id('bac98bb6-7c9a-4f60-a86b-0b2de6b03ef5') @utils.requires_ext(extension="default-networks", service="network") def test_list_default_networks(self): project_id = self.client.tenant_id # non-admin network = self.admin_client.create_network( **{"project_id": project_id})['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, network['id']) default_network = self.admin_client.create_network( **{"project_id": project_id, "is_default": True})['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, default_network['id']) # List networks as a normal user and confirm the default # network extension attribute is returned for those networks # that were created as default networks = self.admin_client.list_networks()['networks'] networks_list = [net['id'] for net in networks] self.assertIn(default_network['id'], networks_list) self.assertIn(network['id'], networks_list) for net in networks: if net['id'] == network['id']: self.assertFalse(net['is_default']) elif net['id'] == default_network['id']: self.assertTrue(net['is_default']) @decorators.idempotent_id('025f4f80-9527-47bd-a0e5-e72f8b6c0509') @utils.requires_ext(extension="default-networks", service="network") def test_show_default_networks_attribute(self): project_id = self.client.tenant_id # non-admin network = self.admin_client.create_network( **{"project_id": project_id})['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, network['id']) default_network = self.admin_client.create_network( **{"project_id": project_id, "is_default": True})['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, default_network['id']) # Show an default network as a normal user and confirm the # default network extension attribute is returned. default_net = self.admin_client.show_network( default_network['id'])['network'] self.assertEqual(default_network['name'], default_net['name']) self.assertEqual(default_network['id'], default_net['id']) self.assertTrue(default_net['is_default']) net = self.admin_client.show_network(network['id'])['network'] # Verify with show that is_default is False for network self.assertEqual(network['name'], net['name']) self.assertEqual(network['id'], net['id']) self.assertFalse(net['is_default'])

commit_message:
Adding below tempest testcase for flavor extension

Associate and disassoicate flavor with
a service profile based one below two api

POST   /v2.0/flavors/{flavor_id}/service_profiles
DELETE /v2.0/flavors/{flavor_id}/service_profiles/{profile_id}

Change-Id: I29e370d58ec08b9d5c80f80784a24aafd17b1d17
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/09/613409/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @decorators.idempotent_id('e2fb2f8c-45bf-429a-9f17-171c70444712') def test_associate_disassociate_flavor_with_service_profiles(self): # verify association of a flavor with a service profile postbody = self.admin_client.create_flavor_service_profile( self.flavor['id'], self.service_profile['id']) self.assertTrue(postbody['service_profile']['id']) # verify the service profile id inside the flavor details getbody = self.admin_client.show_flavor(self.flavor['id']) self.assertEqual(postbody['service_profile']['id'], getbody['flavor']['id']) self.assertTrue(getbody['flavor']['service_profiles']) # verify disassociation of a flavor from a service profile deletebody = self.admin_client.delete_flavor_service_profile( self.flavor['id'], self.service_profile['id']) self.assertFalse(deletebody) # verify service profile was detached from flavor successfully getbody = self.admin_client.show_flavor(self.flavor['id']) self.assertFalse(getbody['flavor']['service_profiles'])

commit_message:
Add api tempest tests for segments

Change-Id: Idf50b10ef8fdace7c5fe31d2266f2d88cdf5cd71
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/57/533257/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 IBM # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.lib.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.lib import decorators from tempest.lib import exceptions from neutron.tests.tempest.api import base from neutron_lib.api.definitions.provider_net import NETWORK_TYPE from neutron_lib.api.definitions.provider_net import PHYSICAL_NETWORK class SegmentsTest(base.BaseAdminNetworkTest): required_extensions = ["segment", "physnet"] def _create_provider_network(self, segments): name = data_utils.rand_name("test-segments") net = self.create_shared_network(network_name=name, segments=segments) self.assertNotEqual('', net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK]) return net def _create_vlan_provider_network(self): return self._create_provider_network( [{NETWORK_TYPE: 'vlan'}]) def _create_vxlan_provider_network(self): return self._create_provider_network( [{NETWORK_TYPE: 'vxlan'}]) @decorators.idempotent_id('8c23ce8e-8896-44cd-98bb-5112c42718d0') def test_segment_create_delete(self): net = self._create_vxlan_provider_network() created_segment = self.admin_client.create_segment( network_id=net['id'], network_type='vxlan') retrieved_segment = self.admin_client.show_segment( created_segment['segment']['id']) self.assertEqual(created_segment['segment']['id'], retrieved_segment['segment']['id']) self.assertNotEqual(0, retrieved_segment['segment']['segmentation_id']) self.assertEqual(net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK], retrieved_segment['segment']['physical_network']) self.assertEqual(net['id'], retrieved_segment['segment']['network_id']) self.assertIsNone(retrieved_segment['segment']['name']) self.assertIsNone(retrieved_segment['segment']['description']) self.assertEqual('vxlan', retrieved_segment['segment']['network_type']) self.admin_client.delete_segment(created_segment['segment']['id']) body = self.admin_client.list_segments() segment_ids = [s['id'] for s in body['segments']] self.assertNotIn(created_segment['segment']['id'], segment_ids) @decorators.idempotent_id('dedf0193-cd2a-4259-bc82-1d5149c85b78') def test_update_segment(self): net = self._create_vxlan_provider_network() segment = self.admin_client.create_segment( network_id=net['id'], network_type='vxlan') self.assertEqual(net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK], segment['segment']['physical_network']) self.assertIsNone(segment['segment']['name']) self.assertIsNone(segment['segment']['description']) segment_name = 'test_segment' segment_description = 'test segment description' self.admin_client.update_segment(segment['segment']['id'], name=segment_name, description=segment_description) segment = self.admin_client.show_segment(segment['segment']['id']) self.assertEqual(segment_name, segment['segment']['name']) self.assertEqual(segment_description, segment['segment']['description']) @decorators.idempotent_id('014b5848-b552-49ef-8fe4-8a5e29f3df0f') def test_subnet_with_segment(self): net = self._create_vxlan_provider_network() segment = self.admin_client.create_segment( network_id=net['id'], network_type='vxlan') self.assertEqual(net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK], segment['segment']['physical_network']) subnet = self.create_subnet(net, client=self.admin_client, segment_id=segment['segment']['id']) subnet = self.admin_client.show_subnet(subnet['id']) self.assertEqual(segment['segment']['id'], subnet['subnet']['segment_id']) @decorators.idempotent_id('648efc75-09b6-4e51-9943-1ad51cc34f17') def test_show_multi_segment_network(self): net = self._create_vxlan_provider_network() self.assertEqual('vxlan', net[NETWORK_TYPE]) self.assertNotEqual(0, net['provider:segmentation_id']) self.admin_client.create_segment( network_id=net['id'], network_type='vxlan') shown_net = self.admin_client.show_network(net['id'])['network'] for segment in shown_net['segments']: self.assertEqual('vxlan', segment[NETWORK_TYPE]) self.assertEqual(net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK], segment[PHYSICAL_NETWORK]) self.assertNotEqual(0, segment['provider:segmentation_id']) @decorators.idempotent_id('0cbc6abd-afa8-44cd-88f8-23666c306215') def test_l2_adjacency(self): net = self._create_vxlan_provider_network() segment = self.admin_client.create_segment( network_id=net['id'], network_type='vxlan') self.assertEqual(net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK], segment['segment']['physical_network']) self.assertTrue(net['l2_adjacency']) self.create_subnet(net, client=self.admin_client, segment_id=segment['segment']['id']) net = self.admin_client.show_network(net['id'])['network'] self.assertFalse(net['l2_adjacency']) @decorators.idempotent_id('48532981-8d6e-45f2-958f-3256354accc2') def test_associate_subnet_to_routed_network_fails(self): net = self._create_vxlan_provider_network() segment = self.admin_client.create_segment( network_id=net['id'], network_type='vxlan') self.assertEqual(net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK], segment['segment']['physical_network']) self.create_subnet(net, client=self.admin_client, segment_id=segment['segment']['id']) e = self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.create_subnet, net, client=self.admin_client) self.assertEqual(400, e.status_code) @decorators.idempotent_id('70391ab0-e2f4-43b7-9ad6-439134005429') def test_delete_network_cascade(self): net = self._create_vxlan_provider_network() segment = self.admin_client.create_segment( network_id=net['id'], network_type='vxlan') self.assertEqual(net[PHYSICAL_NETWORK], segment['segment']['physical_network']) subnet = self.create_subnet(net, client=self.admin_client, segment_id=segment['segment']['id']) self.admin_client.delete_network(net) self.admin_client.show_network(net['id']) e = self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.show_network, net, client=self.admin_client) self.assertEqual(404, e.status_code) self.admin_client.show_subnet(subnet['id']) e = self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.show_subnet, subnet, client=self.admin_client) self.assertEqual(404, e.status_code)

subject: Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-12-11 21:17:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/commit/8051817dd6f3685d1c51168cf53349baaf1bcdd1', 'message': 'Add a Skydive based test

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-12-11 21:17:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/commit/171bf4938682b93b34c0ca61c833a126fdb9523c', 'message': 'Add a Skydive based test

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2018-12-11 21:19:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/commit/e0f40557bd300bace38c5d762d502ba3ff52a811', 'message': '[WIP] Add a Skydive based test

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2018-12-12 14:59:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/commit/f22dd8d1152c717b0f3c838f0229dba7a6781291', 'message': "[WIP] Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test

Skydive [1] is an open source network topology and protocols
analyzer that gives you a comprehensive way to understand
what is happening in your infrastructure.

Miguel Angel Ajo Pelayo and Daniel Alvarez Sanchez gave
a lightning talk [2] in the Denver PTG, showing how
it'd be possible to use Skydive's injection and capture
functionality to test new scenarios that Tempest is unable
to cover.

This patch serves two purposes:
1) Set up the infrastructure to allow Skydive to be used
   in tests.
2) Write the first test that uses Skydive as a reference.

The test asserts that if Neutron claims that a router
is distributed, then traffic to a VM's FIP is indeed
distributed (i.e. goes directly to the compute node
hosting the VM, and not via a gateway or network node).

[1] http://skydive.network/
[2] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-dataplane-testing

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2018-12-12 16:39:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/commit/cc42ecb4047621961d1497946bf00402ef9aadfb', 'message': "[WIP] Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test

commit_message:
Add a Skydive based DVR-multinode test

Skydive [1] is an open source network topology and protocols
analyzer that gives you a comprehensive way to understand
what is happening in your infrastructure.

Miguel Angel Ajo Pelayo and Daniel Alvarez Sanchez gave
a lightning talk [2] in the Denver PTG, showing how
it'd be possible to use Skydive's injection and capture
functionality to test new scenarios that Tempest is unable
to cover.

This patch serves two purposes:
1) Set up the infrastructure to allow Skydive to be used
   in tests.
2) Write the first test that uses Skydive as a reference.

The test asserts that if Neutron claims that a router
is distributed, then traffic to a VM's FIP is indeed
distributed (i.e. goes directly to the compute node
hosting the VM, and not via a gateway or network node).

The patch also reuses the list_AZs and list_hypervisors
methods from another test, and moves them to a common base
class.

[1] http://skydive.network/
[2] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-dataplane-testing

Change-Id: I6cd5021076d3dab56dc16b252ccf99d8bcee1f88
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/94/624494/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function configure_skydive_connection { if ! is_service_enabled skydive-analyzer; then return 0 fi iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG neutron_plugin_options skydive_connection $SKYDIVE_ANALYZER_LISTEN }

commit_message:
Add test_port_security_disabled

The aim of the test is to verify that when a port's port security
is disabled, the port is allowed to send and receive packet using
any MAC address and IP address.
Verifies that issue [1] does not happen.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/networking-ovn/+bug/1815270

Change-Id: I15cfeff8bc76e295154200bd922a05a2d6e3608f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/83/711283/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron_tempest_plugin.common import ssh def _create_server(self, ports): params = { 'flavor_ref': CONF.compute.flavor_ref, 'image_ref': CONF.compute.image_ref, 'key_name': self.keypair['name'], 'networks': [{'port': port['id']} for port in ports]} server = self.create_server(**params) self.wait_for_server_active(server['server']) fip = self.create_floatingip(port=ports[0]) client = ssh.Client(fip['floating_ip_address'], CONF.validation.image_ssh_user, pkey=self.keypair['private_key']) return {'server': server, 'client': client, 'fip': fip} @decorators.idempotent_id('b51a6df9-6d38-4e82-a545-730393f7c591') def test_portsecurity_disabled(self): """Verify that traffic is not blocked when port security is disabled Scenario: 1. Create keypair and router. 2. Create 2 internal networks connected to the router, one is for management and the other one is for testing. Only management subnet will be routed to the external network. 3. Create 2 ports in each network, 2 ports for 2 servers. Ports in the test_network will have specific static ip addresses. 4. Create 2 servers with 2 ports each. 5. Make sure that interfaces connected to the test network are up and running with corresponding ip address. 6. Test that one server (src_server) can reach the other (dst_server) by the ip address configured on the interface connected to the test network. 7. On dst_server change MAC and ip address of the interface connected to the test network. 8. Verify that src_server is still able to access dst_server through the port connected to the test_network even when MAC and ip address do not match the ones configured for the port. """ self.keypair = self.create_keypair() router = self.create_router_by_client() mgmt_network = self.create_network(port_security_enabled=False) test_network = self.create_network(port_security_enabled=False) mgmt_subnet = self.create_subnet( network=mgmt_network, cidr="192.168.0.0/24") test_subnet = self.create_subnet( network=test_network, cidr="192.168.1.0/24", gateway=None) self.create_router_interface(router['id'], mgmt_subnet['id']) ips = {'src_server': '192.168.1.11', 'dst_server': '192.168.1.12', 'dst_server_alt': '192.168.1.13'} src_server_mgmt_port = self.create_port(mgmt_network) dst_server_mgmt_port = self.create_port(mgmt_network) src_server_test_port = self.create_port( test_network, fixed_ips=[{"subnet_id": test_subnet['id'], "ip_address": ips['src_server']}]) dst_server_test_port = self.create_port( test_network, fixed_ips=[{"subnet_id": test_subnet['id'], "ip_address": ips['dst_server']}]) src_server = self._create_server( ports=[src_server_mgmt_port, src_server_test_port]) dst_server = self._create_server( ports=[dst_server_mgmt_port, dst_server_test_port]) servers = {'src_server': src_server, 'dst_server': dst_server} # As both servers use same image we can get interface from any of them shell_path = "PATH=$PATH:/sbin" test_interface = dst_server['client'].exec_command( "{};ip addr | grep {} -B 1 | head -1 | " "cut -d ':' -f 2 | sed 's/[[:space]]//g'".format( shell_path, dst_server_test_port['mac_address'])).rstrip() # In case second interface is down we need to switch it on # and configure ip address for server in servers.keys(): servers[server]['client'].exec_command( "cat /sys/class/net/{interface}/operstate | grep -q -v down " "&& true || ({path}; sudo ip link set {interface} up " "&& sudo ip addr add {ip}/24 dev {interface})".format( path=shell_path, ip=ips[server], interface=test_interface)) self.check_remote_connectivity(src_server['client'], ips['dst_server']) # Now configure another MAC and IP address on the dst_server # test interface and check connectivity again (in both directions) dst_server['client'].exec_command( "{path}; sudo ip addr del {ip}/24 dev {interface} && " "sudo ip addr add {ip_alt}/24 dev {interface} && " "sudo ip link set {interface} address 02:02:02:03:03:03".format( path=shell_path, interface=test_interface, ip=ips['dst_server'], ip_alt=ips['dst_server_alt'])) self.check_remote_connectivity(src_server['client'], ips['dst_server_alt']) self.check_remote_connectivity(dst_server['client'], ips['src_server'])

added_lines: from neutron_tempest_plugin.common import ssh @decorators.idempotent_id('79445698-761e-4f27-a80b-a74d3e8f2eaf') def test_dns_domain_and_name(self): """Test the ability to ping a VM's hostname from another VM. 1) Create two VMs on the same network, giving each a name 2) SSH in to the first VM: 2.1) ping the other VM's internal IP 2.2) ping the other VM's hostname """ server = self._create_server(name='luke') self.create_pingable_secgroup_rule( secgroup_id=self.security_groups[-1]['id']) server_ip = server['fip']['floating_ip_address'] self.check_connectivity(server_ip, CONF.validation.image_ssh_user, self.keypair['private_key']) leia = self.create_server( flavor_ref=CONF.compute.flavor_ref, image_ref=CONF.compute.image_ref, key_name=self.keypair['name'], networks=[{'uuid': self.network['id']}], security_groups=[ {'name': self.security_groups[-1]['name']}], name='leia') self.wait_for_server_active(leia['server']) ssh_client = ssh.Client( server_ip, CONF.validation.image_ssh_user, pkey=self.keypair['private_key']) self.assertIn('luke', ssh_client.exec_command('hostname')) leia_port = self.client.list_ports( network_id=self.network['id'], device_id=leia['server']['id'])['ports'][0] # Ping with a higher timeout because spawning 2 VMs in some # environment can put significant load on the deployment, resulting # in very long boot times. self.check_remote_connectivity( ssh_client, leia_port['fixed_ips'][0]['ip_address'], timeout=CONF.validation.ping_timeout * 10, servers=[server, leia]) resolv_conf = ssh_client.exec_command('cat /etc/resolv.conf') self.assertIn('openstackgate.local', resolv_conf) self.assertNotIn(self.zone['name'], resolv_conf) self.check_remote_connectivity(ssh_client, 'leia', servers=[server, leia]) self.check_remote_connectivity(ssh_client, 'leia.openstackgate.local', servers=[server, leia])

commit_message:
Add VRRP failover test

The aim of the test is to validate that in case master VM becomes not
available the traffic to the VIP is directed to the second VM.
Such scenario is often used for example in environments with Octavia
load balancers.

Scenario:
- Create a port for VRRP VIP and ports for VMs with
  allowed address pair configured to the VIP IP
- Create two VMs and setup VRRP between the VMs
- Test traffic to virtual IP (login via ssh)
- Shut off active VM
- Test traffic to virtual IP. Traffic should now flow to the second VM

Change-Id: I0dce852066b3931300a1fbd095c69e64c872fcf8

commit_message:
Fix test coverage for old OS/puppet versions

This change fixes how old OS versions and puppet versions are tested
and now we use only the combinations supported in the past, instead of
testing the all combinations which contain some invalid ones like
Puppet 5 + CentOS Stream 9.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/876554
Change-Id: Ie22c586c6f0e8cfe82a46bd62d3953af1918e777

commit_message:
Rename cloud-credentials relation to homogeinize with the stack

Keystone relations are `identity-service` and `identity-credentials`.
Every charm using `keystone` interface (with `identity-service` name)
call it `identity-service`. Horizon calling the interface `keystone-credentials`
with `cloud-credentials` name is an exception.

Change-Id: I6ca98201abd32d58a3d1476d8a9477cc5f40080b

commit_message:
Consume upper-constraints

As of now this project does not use upper-constraints due to
which latest releases of dependencies get installed.
This often breaks the project's functionality further leading
to failed CI jobs. Using upper-constraints will prevent
installation of incompatible releases of the project dependencies.

Pinning sqlalchemy packages introduced in change
5a8598c436a14efb1c718afe8ce1d0221d77104a is no longer needed.

Change-Id: I576d30313042383bd127bbce55ceccaa056d25b7

commit_message:
Enforce image safety during image_conversion

This does two things:

1. It makes us check that the QCOW backing_file is unset on those
types of images. Nova and Cinder do this already to prevent an
arbitrary (and trivial to accomplish) host file exposure exploit.
2. It makes us restrict VMDK files to only allowed subtypes. These
files can name arbitrary files on disk as extents, providing the
same sort of attack. Default that list to just the types we believe
are actually useful for openstack, and which are monolithic.

The configuration option to specify allowed subtypes is added in
glance's config and not in the import options so that we can extend
this check later to image ingest. The format_inspector can tell us
what the type and subtype is, and we could reject those images early
and even in the case where image_conversion is not enabled.

Some changes were required in the backport in order to pass the CI:
Pep8 fix: ignore H703 errors.
Py27 fix: FileNotFoundError did not exist in Python2.7.

Closes-Bug: #1996188
Change-Id: Idf561f6306cebf756c787d8eefdc452ce44bd5e0
(cherry picked from commit 0d6282a01691cecc2798f7858b181c4bb30f850c)
(cherry picked from commit 4967ab6935cfd0274ae801ac943d01909a236a0a)
(cherry picked from commit dc8e5a5cc7f5e9d1b697e520a7533cc90516db1b)
(cherry picked from commit f45b5f024e765f0000884dfec5ac222124cfbc6d)
(cherry picked from commit 9a98c4a7d1358cdae009cc8fb6377160a126ea7b)

added_lines: if 'backing-filename' in metadata: LOG.warning('Refusing to process QCOW image with a backing file') raise RuntimeError( 'QCOW images with backing files are not allowed') if metadata.get('format') == 'vmdk': create_type = metadata.get( 'format-specific', {}).get( 'data', {}).get('create-type') allowed = CONF.image_format.vmdk_allowed_types if not create_type: raise RuntimeError(_('Unable to determine VMDK create-type')) if not len(allowed): LOG.warning(_('Refusing to process VMDK file as ' 'vmdk_allowed_types is empty')) raise RuntimeError(_('Image is a VMDK, but no VMDK createType ' 'is specified')) if create_type not in allowed: LOG.warning(_('Refusing to process VMDK file with create-type ' 'of %r which is not in allowed set of: %s'), create_type, ','.join(allowed)) raise RuntimeError(_('Invalid VMDK create-type specified'))

commit_message:
ovs: fix regression when vlan mapping is not already registered

Bug introduced by Ic3c147136549b17aea0fe78e930a41a5b33ab9d8, when a
VLAN mapping is not registered during a call to
update_network_segement, the function should return None.

Closes-Bug: #2009215
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@industrialdiscipline.com>
Change-Id: I91f8e8bd18d9956216e5715c658dfb408a2cbf07

commit_message:
Fix NetApp NFS driver to never spawn a native thread again

The NetApp NFS driver is spawning a Python native thread to
schedule image cache cleanups, which can lead to unpredictable
behavior such as thread starvation due to its hunger to preempt
other Cinder's fellow threads.

This patch fixes it by reimplementing the NFS image cache cleanup
task as a green thread with a customized periodic interval.

The patch adds the configuration
option ´netapp_nfs_image_cache_cleanup_interval´ to allow
operators to set an interval in seconds between calls to the image
cleanup task.

Closes-Bug: #2008017
Change-Id: I609a4f056d19f67aa7b8113bb38b9e9083f24124
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/78/853678/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.IntOpt('netapp_nfs_image_cache_cleanup_interval', default=600, min=60, help=('Sets time in seconds between NFS image cache ' 'cleanup tasks.')),

commit_message:
Fix the way how default SG for project if found in SG scenario test

Previously it was just getting list of SGs and assumed that first one in
the list is the "default" one. It's not always true so now there is
helper method which lists of SGs for project and looks for the one with
name "default" as this name is hardcoded in Neutron.

Change-Id: I608677547c9c8ae00af8821622cefa0955d692c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin refs/changes/52/876052/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use certbot to generate SSL cert for the external VIP in 'stepca' scenario

This patch uses the certbot functionality to issue a certificate
from a locally installed ACME server on the AIO node, when the
string 'stepca' appears in the scenario.

This allows testing of the certbot code in the haproxy role and the
wider integration with Openstack-Ansible to be tested in CI jobs.

Add test jobs for integrated repo and also infra jobs for haproxy roles.
Change-Id: Ide769f54505898630aae67e25b238624ba4f4fdb

Change-Id: Iaefc648b06e877117da23ceec109dc77a96db6df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/93/876693/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Use the locally deployed Step-CA ACME server to configure the # certificate for the haproxy external VIP # SSL setup haproxy_ssl: true haproxy_ssl_letsencrypt_enable: True haproxy_ssl_letsencrypt_install_method: "distro" haproxy_ssl_letsencrypt_certbot_server: "https://127.0.0.1:8889/acme/acme-osa/directory" # openstack_hosts role should ensure that everthing trusts the Step-CA roots openstack_host_ca_certificates: - name: StepCARoot.crt src: /opt/step_ca_roots.pem

commit_message:
Fix list-deliverables command to use release-id

With the new release identification / naming schema [1] (like:
2023.1 Antelope) new stable branch naming was introduced (like:
stable/2023.1). This was not handled in the list-deliverables command as it
still uses the release name. This patch fixes this by reading the
'release-id' field from series_status.yaml and if present then uses it
as stable/<release-id> for the branch creation.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/release-naming.html

Change-Id: Id6a03024fa2268ba233189abfe48556d3530daef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/57/876557/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from openstack_releases import series_status def get_stable_branch_id(series): """Retrieve the stable branch ID of the series. Returns the release-id if the series has such field, otherwise returns the series name. This is needed for the new stable branch naming style: stable/2023.1 (versus the old style: stable/zed). """ series_status_data = series_status.SeriesStatus.default() release_id = series_status_data[series].release_id if release_id is None: release_id = series return str(release_id) if deliv.get_branch_location('stable/' + get_stable_branch_id(series)) is not None:
deleted_lines: if deliv.get_branch_location('stable/' + series) is not None:

commit_message:
Release Horizon 23.1.0 as the final tag for 2023.1

This patch cut the first release of horizon which
can be used to create a stable/2023.1 branch.

Change-Id: I6a4527e2bfe3e384fd61be64f48f135ba40c6d08

commit_message:
remove unicode prefix from code

All strings are considered as unicode string from Python 3.

This patch drops the explicit unicode literal (u'...')
appearances from the unicode strings.

Change-Id: I73b566f35bf30cc9e8b4124c357b1470233d6ec1

subject: POC: Fix sort order for stable/2023.1 release
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-03-03 21:19:29.000000000', 'files': ['reno/scanner.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/reno/commit/4df19e8df087f496ea6f31867b52a046447769ae', 'message': 'POC: Fix sort order for stable/2023.1 release

The old behaviour is to use standard sort order for branch names, which
places the recently created stable/2023.1 branch in front of all
previous stable/[a-z] branches. Fix this by adding a key function that
will make stable/2* sort as stable/zzz2*.

TODO: make this more generic for people using branch_name_re other than
stable/*

Change-Id: I6f290c3a49768252a12cc227050aa4e29ee243b4
'}]
commit_message:
POC: Fix sort order for stable/2023.1 release

The old behaviour is to use standard sort order for branch names, which
places the recently created stable/2023.1 branch in front of all
previous stable/[a-z] branches. Fix this by adding a key function that
will make stable/2* sort as stable/zzz2*.

TODO: make this more generic for people using branch_name_re other than
stable/*

Change-Id: I6f290c3a49768252a12cc227050aa4e29ee243b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/reno refs/changes/40/876440/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def sort_key(name): if name.startswith('stable/2'): return 'stable/zzz' + name[8:] return name return list(sorted(branch_names, key=sort_key))

commit_message:
[stable-only] Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Idb2995a178f60650fef66d7a2c6e9943fbd81da7

commit_message:
OAuth 2.0 Mutual-TLS Support

Added a new OAuth2mTlsClientCredential plugin, accessible via the
'v3oauth2mtlsclientcredential' entry point, making possible to
authenticate using an OAuth 2.0 Mutual-TLS client credentials.

Co-Authored-By: Hiromu Asahina <hiromu.asahina.az@hco.ntt.co.jp>
Change-Id: I0e02ef18da5d60cdd1bcde07b07c2071b74b73d6
Implements: blueprint support-oauth2-mtls

added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes the iteration to obtain the address_scope linked to a subnet. A network can be linked to more than one subnet (ipv4 and ipv6), but if one of them does not have an address_scope, a null object element access failure occured. See bug `1998104 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1998104>`_.

commit_message:
Update master for stable/2023.1

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/2023.1.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/2023.1.

Sem-Ver: feature
Change-Id: If400681138cdb2b63790567bed6354ade2a49f8b

commit_message:
Reintroduce agent bridge resync test

It appears we have changed the test_agent_resync_on_non_existing_bridgetest
main purpose in change 709544[1]. The test is no longer testing on what is
describing it will test, i.e. resync on bridge change. Testing resync on
a bridge change is still important. I feel like what the test is testing
is already covered in _test_agent_events set of tests.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/709544

Change-Id: I8f164c12db7c4c1aa54ba07feede3586e6a19381
(cherry picked from commit 75e83602247360cf10b7b9aa4e53a0135b491cae)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/66/876466/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _create_logical_switch_port(self, type_=None, addresses=None): if addresses: lswitch_port_columns['addresses'] = addresses def test_agent_resync_on_non_existing_bridge(self): BR_NEW = 'br-new' self._mock_get_ovn_br.return_value = BR_NEW self.agent.ovs_idl.list_br.return_value.execute.return_value = [BR_NEW] # NOTE: The IP address is specifically picked such that it fits the # metadata port external_ids: { neutron:cidrs }. This is because agent # will only trigger if the logical port is part of a neutron subnet lswitchport_name, _ = self._create_logical_switch_port( addresses='AA:AA:AA:AA:AA:AB 192.168.122.125' ) exc = Exception("Agent bridge hasn't changed from %s to %s " "in 10 seconds after Port_Binding event" % (self.agent.ovn_bridge, BR_NEW)) n_utils.wait_until_true( lambda: BR_NEW == self.agent.ovn_bridge, timeout=10, exception=exc)
deleted_lines: def _create_logical_switch_port(self, type_=None): @mock.patch.object(agent.PortBindingChassisCreatedEvent, 'run') def test_agent_resync_on_non_existing_bridge(self, mock_pbinding): lswitchport_name, _ = self._create_logical_switch_port() exc = Exception('PortBindingChassisCreatedEvent was not called') def check_mock_pbinding(): if mock_pbinding.call_count < 1: return False args = mock_pbinding.call_args[0] self.assertEqual('update', args[0]) self.assertEqual(lswitchport_name, args[1].logical_port) self.assertEqual(self.chassis_name, args[1].chassis[0].name) return True n_utils.wait_until_true(check_mock_pbinding, timeout=10, exception=exc)

commit_message:
Reintroduce agent bridge resync test

It appears we have changed the test_agent_resync_on_non_existing_bridgetest
main purpose in change 709544[1]. The test is no longer testing on what is
describing it will test, i.e. resync on bridge change. Testing resync on
a bridge change is still important. I feel like what the test is testing
is already covered in _test_agent_events set of tests.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/709544

Change-Id: I8f164c12db7c4c1aa54ba07feede3586e6a19381
(cherry picked from commit 75e83602247360cf10b7b9aa4e53a0135b491cae)

commit_message:
Pin tox to < 4.0.0

Tox 4.0.0 was recently released and it has several breaking changes.
We pin to < 4.0.0 here. We are planning to move forward only on the
master charm branches.

Tox is also pinned to < 4.0.0 for stable branches in upstream
openstack-zuul-jobs as well as in zosci-config. However, the
requires= section in the charm's tox.ini file ends up installing
tox>4, wiping out the zuul-pinned tox<4 that was already installed
installed. This patch fixes that.

Related-Bug: #2002788
Change-Id: I92bc88c044cc1dd1ca65ae59273d8ff9c20f9812

added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes the iteration to obtain the address_scope linked to a subnet. A network can be linked to more than one subnet (ipv4 and ipv6), but if one of them does not have an address_scope, a null object element access failure occured. See bug `1998104 <https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1998104>`_.

commit_message:
Reintroduce agent bridge resync test

It appears we have changed the test_agent_resync_on_non_existing_bridgetest
main purpose in change 709544[1]. The test is no longer testing on what is
describing it will test, i.e. resync on bridge change. Testing resync on
a bridge change is still important. I feel like what the test is testing
is already covered in _test_agent_events set of tests.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/709544

(cherry picked from commit 75e83602247360cf10b7b9aa4e53a0135b491cae)

commit_message:
Add affiliation lookup functionality

Per OpenInfra Foundation bylaws, fewer than half of the TC members
are allowed t be affiliated with the same organization. In order to
make it easier to find this information, add scripts to look up
affiliation information in the foundation member directory.

Change-Id: I7275411fad3887cc6b9d5bf9152231a6cc6fddba

commit_message:
Drop Mesos code

The coe mesos has not been maintained for quite some
time and hasn't got much attention from the community
in general. As discussed in the mailing list [1] we
are dropping for now.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-December/026230.html

Co-Authored-By: jake.yip@ardc.edu.au

Change-Id: Ie7de9a37bfad6214f52d0605409e74d62a51df47

commit_message:
Drop empty elements from constraint/requirement files

We should filter out empty elements from lists that are provided as
input to the role, to ensure idempotence of build constraints and
requirements file as a result.

Additionally to that we should ensure to control jinja whitespaces
not to add extra new lines to the end of files.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/872896
Change-Id: Ide47712f775c91d90b749bc8e4d8f87c5bd658f2
Closes-Bug: #2004546
(cherry picked from commit 2a25337b9844b4b8a90420e864ee38e8168ce586)

commit_message:
Order branches according to OpenStack release names

OpenStack has changed the naming scheme for stable branches after
reaching the end of the alphabet. In order to make sure that the new
branches like stable/2023.1 are sorted after the previous names like
stable/zed, two new variables are introduced that control the sorting
behaviour.

Change-Id: I489dd7a811ebd09c16ecb1f85a0a2e162146962a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/reno refs/changes/81/876581/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def openstack_sort_key(name): if name.startswith('stable/2'): return 'stable/zzz' + name[8:] return name if self.conf.openstack_branch_ordering: return list(sorted(branch_names, key=openstack_sort_key))

Use juju secrets for keystone-credentials

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/2023.1

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/2023.1 branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I59d59c94c1ba1e378e90f0cd31d737195c7c0d88

commit_message:
Change the release tag to use the release identification

According to the TC resolution [1] and the release identification
document [2], the release number will be used as primary identifier in
the development cycle. Release name will be used in marketing.

[1]https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20220524-release-identification-process.html
[2]https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/release-naming.html

Change-Id: Ia3da9bf6d6113edacb0e21de9a51bd60d5e2465b

commit_message:
Add authentication for [cinder] section of nova.conf

Nova complains about an inability to access endpoint list for block
storage. This patch updates nova.conf with the respective configuration.:

Example errors in nova-compute log:

1. The [cinder] section of your nova configuration file must be configured
for authentication with the block-storage service endpoint.

2. Delete attachment failed for attachment <UUID>. Error: Unknown auth type:
None (HTTP 401) Code: 401: cinderclient.exceptions.Unauthorized:
Unknown auth type: None (HTTP 401)

Change-Id: I4c1ae32ed078a4412ff44b7ac3f921b223d0cba3
(cherry picked from commit 69df45b068ade8311ace9ef30745bd229ed9ea24)

subject: spec: nova Dynamic scheduler system
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-01-30 21:40:56.000000000', 'files': ['specs/2023.1/approved/nova-dynamic-scheduler-system.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/99f8bb254b7e9fcb4d0ba5800925060b7ea11fd9', 'message': 'spec: nova Dynamic scheduler system

Implement: bp/dynamic-scheduler-system
Change-Id: I9e4a90d846be62efe0bad53f0853fe1918f1df4b
'}]
commit_message:
spec: nova Dynamic scheduler system

Implement: bp/dynamic-scheduler-system
Change-Id: I9e4a90d846be62efe0bad53f0853fe1918f1df4b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/25/872225/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Nova Dynamic scheduler system ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/dynamic-scheduler-system The virtual machine (VM) scheduling system in Nova provides an interface for operators to create their own scheduler algorithms. The custom algorithms have to be coded in Python and added/configured in the Nova scheduler agent. To enable a certain level of dynamism and flexibility which are intrinsic in a Cloud Computing environment, Nova has a JSON scheduler filter, which makes use of a scheduler hint called `query` with a JSON expression that enables one to create simple algorithm such as selecting a host with name "x" or some other host attribute. However, that forces cloud providers to build/use custom front end systems, which in some cases might not be practical. Problem description =================== The JSON scheduler is an interesting approach providing flexibility to operators. That is quite useful when one uses a customer dashboard on top of OpenStack, and that portal can set these metadata when allocating virtual machines. However, for cloud systems that want to use only OpenStack without any other layer of abstraction that is not practical to persist/configure a scheduling algorithm for each VM. Moreover, the JSON scheduler is limited to executing string matching with the attributes found in the host definition, and one cannot use data from the VM itself, such as project ID, name, flavor, and so on. On the other hand, creating a new scheduler in Python might not be feasible for some operators as they are not that familiar with the language and processes to manage such code. Use Cases --------- There are different use cases that could be addressed. The basic need is the ability to easily create scheduler algorithms, and manage them in a more operator-friendly format. We already do something similar at Ceilometer [1]. Proposed change =============== With the presented context in mind, we look at Ceilometer dynamic pollsters sub-system [1], where a similar situation was faced. There (in Ceilometer), it was created an extension that enables operators to create pollsters using the YML syntax. Therefore, we are proposing a similar solution for Nova schedulers, where operators can easily create their own rules via the YML syntax, and apply/combine these rules with data gathered from other contexts (not limited to Nova). We are proposing a YML design with the following options: - name (mandatory): the name of the dynamic scheduler that the YML defines - skip_rules (optional): a set of rules (simple Python operations) that determine if the scheduler should be ignored. If one of the rules solves to ``True``, thd scheduler is not executed. The previous skip evaluation can be obtained in the subsequent executions via the `value` variable (the initial value is `None`). - backend_ops (optional): a set of rules (simple Python operations) that determine if the backend (Nova compute host) can/should be considered for the scheduling algorithm. If no rule is created, the default is ``True``. - scheduling_ops (optional): a set of rules (simple Python operations) that determine which backends (Nova compute host) can/should be considered for the scheduling algorithm. If no rule is created, the default is ``True``. This process is executed with the resulting list of ``backend_ops``. Therefore, at this step, we can see all resulting backends, and decide which one should be kept, and even sort them in our preferred order together while filtering the elements for the other scheduling filters that might be enabled. - endpoint_type (optional): defines the endpoint type that is used to discover the base URL of the component where we gather metadata to feed in the scheduling algorithm; for Keystone, one can use ``identity``. Other values are accepted such as volume for cinder endpoints, object-store for swift, and so on. If this option is not configured, extra metadata are not captured. Once a URL is configured, the response is loaded into a variable called ``extra_scheduling_metadata``; - url_path (optional): defines the path of the request that we execute on the endpoint to gather data. For example, to gather data from Keystone, regarding users, one can use ``/v3/users``; - next_sample_url (optional): if the consumed API returns a linked response that contains a link to the next response set (page), the system can be configured to follow these links and join all linked responses into a single one. Similarly to ``scheduling_ops`` , ``backend_ops``, and ``skip_rules``, operators can use this option to generate the next sample URL path to execute the next request to handle paged responses. If the rules here return ``None``, or if the option is not configured, we assume that there is no next page to execute requests to; - headers (optional): it is a map of ``key`` and ``value`` that can be used to customize the header of the request that is executed against the URL. Workflows ------------ The dynamic filters, when enabled, execute the following process: - Load the YML configuration that describes all of the dynamic schedulers that are configured in the Nova scheduler; - For each scheduler defined in the YML, we execute the process serially; reading from top to bottom of the file, the result of the first dynamic scheduler will be used to feed the next one, and so on. Then, after the dynamic scheduling is finished, its result is returned to the scheduling system to proceed with the other schedulers, if configured; - For each scheduler, we check if there are the ``endpoint_type`` and ``url_path``configured. If there is none, we move on to the next step. If there is a configuration, we execute the request and store its output. After the first response is retrieved, if there is ``next_sample_url``, we use it to generate the next URL to call. If there is, we merge their responses. - After loading the metadata, we proceed to the scheduling part. We first call ``backend_ops`` to filter the backends that should be considered for the scheduling; - After filtering all backends, we move on with the global scheduling algorithm, where one can execute the scheduling with a global perspective on the parameters, all available backends, the request specification to allocate the resource, and some metadata allocated; - The result is returned to the scheduling manager. Alternatives ------------ The alternative is to either use the ``JsonFilter``, which is rather limited and needs to be configured in a virtual machine basis or creating custom scheduler filter that needs to be coded in Python. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ It will depend on the algorithm created by the operators. If, for instance, the system downloads metadata, and that makes the scheduler a bit slower, we can also work in a future iteration to add caching mechanism and so on. Other deployer impact --------------------- Needs to handle the dynamic scheduling system YML file, if one wants to use this feature. recreate all the instances in their cloud? Developer impact ---------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: - Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org Work Items ---------- - Discuss and improve the blueprint/spec for this proposal - Merge the spec - Propose the patch that implements the spec - Discuss and improve the patch that impllements this proposal Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tested, as we did for [1]. Documentation Impact ==================== Need to document this scheduling sub-system and its features. Similar to what we did in [1]. References ========== [1] https://docs.openstack.org/ceilometer/latest/admin/telemetry-dynamic-pollster.html

subject: Allow maridbcheck socket to FreeBind
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-02-22 08:07:41.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/galera_server_post_install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server/commit/4acaf657873452e0720a1b3f5ba2f889ab88d96e', 'message': "Allow maridbcheck socket to FreeBind

Once we've removed network.target from wanted targets for
mariadbcheck.socket, it started to fail to startup intermitently in LXC
deployments, since it was trying to bind on IP address that is not
brought up yet. At the same time we can't wait for IP being up, as
OVS while providing network, waits for socket.target as it needs
to have ovsdb started up, so waiting for network.target does
create circular dependency.

To avoid that we're allowing socket to bind on IP even when IP is not
UP yet. Other possible solution would be to bind on 0.0.0.0.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/872896
Change-Id: Ia4cde2153813e68419d261cd94e3017523177142
Closes-Bug: #2003631
Related-Bug: #2002653
(cherry picked from commit 8a8d29ea490fba6695e3356831846466f6991089)
"}]
commit_message:
Allow maridbcheck socket to FreeBind

Once we've removed network.target from wanted targets for
mariadbcheck.socket, it started to fail to startup intermitently in LXC
deployments, since it was trying to bind on IP address that is not
brought up yet. At the same time we can't wait for IP being up, as
OVS while providing network, waits for socket.target as it needs
to have ovsdb started up, so waiting for network.target does
create circular dependency.

To avoid that we're allowing socket to bind on IP even when IP is not
UP yet. Other possible solution would be to bind on 0.0.0.0.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-ansible/+/872896
Change-Id: Ia4cde2153813e68419d261cd94e3017523177142
Closes-Bug: #2003631
Related-Bug: #2002653
(cherry picked from commit 8a8d29ea490fba6695e3356831846466f6991089)

commit_message:
[CI] Ceph/NFS: skip data-intensive tests with ipv6

We're running test_create_shrink_and_write
and test_create_extend_and_write tests twice,
changing only the client VM's IP address family.
Not much value in running all of these since we're
exhausting the disk space with these tests. We can
choose to re-enable these tests when the situation
changes with either the footprint of the tests
or the form factor of the devstack node.

Partial-Bug: #2009083
Change-Id: I868b2e40934e5d10eb0c5cc6fa867e6adc2cc9fc
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Use juju secrets for TLS private key

TLS private key for each unit is saved
in the peer data as plain text. Instead
the private key can be saved as juju
secret.

Change-Id: I29667115e67ceb552a8afdaef6361b0eb9b65ed1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ops-sunbeam refs/changes/10/876710/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if "private_key" in peer_relation.data[self.charm.model.unit]: # Secret already saved in peer_relation return private_key_secret = self.model.app.add_secret( {"private-key": private_key.decode()}, label=f"{self.charm.model.unit}-private-key", ) "private_key": private_key_secret.id, private_key = None private_key_secret_id = peer_relation.data[self.charm.model.unit].get( if private_key_secret_id: private_key_secret = self.model.get_secret( id=private_key_secret_id ) private_key = private_key_secret.get_content().get("private-key") key = None private_key_secret_id = peer_relation.data[self.charm.model.unit].get( "private_key" if private_key_secret_id: private_key_secret = self.model.get_secret( id=private_key_secret_id ) key = private_key_secret.get_content().get("private-key")

commit_message:
Release heat RC1 for Antelope

This proposed a RC1 release for heat to get any merged changes
out prior to the RC1 deadline for Antelope going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by early Friday, March 03.

$ git log --oneline --no-merges 19.0.0.0rc1..604111b0b
604111b0b Fix setting the tempest virtual env constraints env var
8e2286c9b Fix unit tests for python-barbicanclient 5.5.0
85480f94d Fix an assert statement
29eaf4ef7 Use new get_rpc_client API from oslo.messaging
a0ff4b98b Decode UTF-8 body data in SwiftSignal
1305a3152 Honor 'hidden' parameter in 'stack environment show' command
b452ea708 Skip test_stack_update_with_replacing_userdata
53fa8c374 Explicitly pass error kwarg in nested StackValidationFailed
500201cb7 Skip test_cancel_update_server_with_port
9407b4897 Ignore resource_data decryption errors
ceef7869e Don't load all resources for policy check
5451b9854 Imported Translations from Zanata
0aa0b3825 Update stestr args for inclusive language
56d99bf65 Improve map_merge logging
ddbf9db52 Set cache_ok to avoid further SAWarning
0ea1ee087 Retry to detach volume if nova returned error 409
13fbd367e Fix get_attr syntax in template guide
87bdbfdca Drop implementation for OS::Magnum::Bay/BayModel
ba29a7089 Switch to 2023.1 Python3 unit tests and generic template name
1b42c7296 Update master for stable/zed
af5ffbe01 Replace deprecated Query.as_scalar()
e17f68a83 Deploy healthcheck middleware as app instead of filter
520e2389d Allow deleting user_creds when can't be decrypted

Signed-off-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I023233da893c04b4891ea38c3aec13ec50155574

commit_message:
Add protection for races around expose_subnet

This patch adds protection to expose_subnet in case by the time
the event is processed the peer is not yet linked or already
deleted

Change-Id: I0d3872d31055d94766b7483e074bd417e852fd2f

commit_message:
More protection from router deletion races

This patch adds protection when processing an expose_subnet action
in case the router gets deleted before the event gets processed

Change-Id: I2d07c77568f7ea51f464c4185d9e28f5e477174f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ovn-bgp-agent refs/changes/77/876277/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Enable policy rule management in nova-compute

There are some features in nova-compute which validate policy rules.
For example when connecting an instance to an external network,
nova-compute checks ``network:attach_external_network`` to determine
whether the operation is permitted.

This change migrates definition of nova::policy hieradata from nova-api
to nova-base so that the hieradata can be used by both nova-api and
nova-compute.

Conflicts:
	deployment/nova/nova-api-container-puppet.yaml
        deployment/nova/nova-base-puppet.yaml

Note that conflicts in deployment/nova/nova-base-puppet.yaml , which
are caused by a few tht parameters to inject additional policy rules,
are not detected by git properly.

Closes-Bug: #1955786
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/824690
Change-Id: I90be98d67ede06933bbcf3ad5448365ea220f1a9
(cherry picked from commit 2a27e8bdbb5655851a65163ff968546233ce0e60)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/05/867605/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NovaApiPolicies: description: | A hash of policies to configure for Nova API. e.g. { nova-context_is_admin: { key: context_is_admin, value: 'role:admin' } } default: {} type: json EnforceSecureRbac: type: boolean default: false description: >- Setting this option to True will configure each OpenStack service to enforce Secure RBAC by setting `[oslo_policy] enforce_new_defaults` and `[oslo_policy] enforce_scope` to True. This introduces a consistent set of RBAC personas across OpenStack services that include support for system and project scope, as well as keystone's default roles, admin, member, and reader. Do not enable this functionality until all services in your deployment actually support secure RBAC. nova::policy::enforce_new_defaults: {get_param: EnforceSecureRbac} nova::policy::enforce_scope: {get_param: EnforceSecureRbac} nova::policy::policies: {get_param: NovaApiPolicies}

commit_message:
Enable policy rule management in nova-compute

There are some features in nova-compute which validate policy rules.
For example when connecting an instance to an external network,
nova-compute checks ``network:attach_external_network`` to determine
whether the operation is permitted.

This change makes sure that the nova policy file in compute nodes are
also managed by puppet-tripleo.

Conflicts:
	spec/classes/tripleo_profile_base_nova_compute_spec.rb

Partial-Bug: #1955786
Change-Id: I490cc558238719d4c9585e2a57497d1b1787a9ed
(cherry picked from commit 6cc58e8ac46ec0d4a0b3208b05eaccb289905e31)

commit_message:
Release keystone RC1 for Antelope

This proposed a RC1 release for keystone to get any merged changes
out prior to the RC1 deadline for Antelope going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by early Friday, March 03.

Signed-off-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I79d3803112901d8cdc228b76dd238f39cc85215c

commit_message:
Instance unexpected shutdown when source node startup

Before shutdown the instance, the source node was breakdown, caused that
the shutdown instance message remained in queue and could not be
consumed, message was not consumed until the source node was started.
When the source node was up, continuing to execute the stop operation,
and the instance vm_state was changed to STOPPED, the periodic task of
synchronized power state _sync_power_states was captured and triggered
the shutdown operation.

Not only the instance shutdown operation, but also the operations
related to the status of the source node where the instance is located
is abnormal, the operation on the instance may cause unexpected
exceptions, so they are limited.

Related-Bug: 2008876

Change-Id: I78ad2b4eedd6fbd1d414e04fa9a1da62ea2fae1c

commit_message:
Fix typo in quorum-related variables for RabbitMQ

In [1] there was a typo made in variable names. To prevent even futher
awkwardness regarding variable naming, we fix typo and publish a
release note for ones that already using variables in their deployments.

commit_message:
Remove duplicate rows in MySQL query output

Previously we would expect duplicates rows from MySQL and then filter
them with _unique_floatingip_iterator. This means that we were
converting rows to ORM-mapped objects unnecessarily. This conversion is
very CPU intensive.

Instead, we can remove the duplicates as a part of the query which means
that only unique rows are returned and the number of conversions from
rows to ORM-mapped objects is reduced significantly. It also means that
the _unique_floatingip_iterator function is no longer needed.

Change-Id: I05136302f7b8abc0a985b91c993008595234ad6b
Signed-off-by: Adam Oswick <adam@adamoswick.co.uk>

deleted_lines: import itertools return cls._unique_floatingip_iterator(context, query) @classmethod def _unique_floatingip_iterator(cls, context, query): """Iterates over only one row per floating ip. Ignores others.""" # Group rows by fip id. They must be sorted by same. q = query.order_by(l3.FloatingIP.id) keyfunc = lambda row: row[0]['id'] group_iterator = itertools.groupby(q, keyfunc) # Just hit the first row of each group for key, value in group_iterator: # pylint: disable=stop-iteration-return row = list(next(value))

commit_message:
Add actions to regenerate password

Add regenerate-password action to regenerate
passwords for admin, charm or service user.

Remove KeystonepasswordManager class.

Update zaza-smoke-test job to mandatory.

Change-Id: I542894149b533da4cba5371f7412d4cbcc21e305
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-keystone-k8s refs/changes/80/866680/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # All the users created by charm is at domain level but # not yet project level, so projectname is not a param. regenerate-password: description: Regenerate password for the given user params: username: type: string description: The username for the account. domainname: type: string default: admin_domain description: Domain name the user is created in. required: - username additionalProperties: False

commit_message:
Change the type of test_duration to "float"

Currently, the test_duration field has a "string" type which prevents
us from making the following query: "What is the test with the highest
test duration value?".

This patch changes the type of test_duration to "float". This ensures
that the value is registered by ElasticSearch as a number.

Change-Id: I4fb803f29f2e68a70a282e214caeefb853f7a538

commit_message:
Release solum-dashboard RC1 for Antelope

This proposed a RC1 release for solum-dashboard to get any merged changes
out prior to the RC1 deadline for Antelope going into effect.

If the team is ready to proceed, please leave a +1 to acknowledge this
release and we will process right away. If the team is working on any
final merges, leave a -1 with some detail on the status and update the
patch with the new commit hash to use when ready.

Patches with no response will be merged by early Friday, March 03.

Signed-off-by: Hervé Beraud <hberaud@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I89f7f650341a16a1aa9980ab4c02788b10532ea1

subject: Inventory: Track seen nets, add/get new nets only
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2023-02-08 16:56:42.000000000', 'files': ['tripleo_common/inventory.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/e16e03a4b1bd2f4c124018a576da5e30e9b91b8b', 'message': "Inventory: Track seen nets, add/get new nets only

Before this change we fetched many duplicats of the
same network - i.e for every port even if the ports
are on a network we already collected. Subsequently
we got the subnet of all networks in the list which
contained many duplicates.

With this change we keep track of seen network's and
only get networks and subnets from the network service
once.

This reduces the number of calls to neutron by a huge
amount in larger scale deployments. In my 250 node
test enviornment for comparision.

OLD: Generate ansible inventory | localhost | 0:09:35.990553 | 124.56s
NEW: Generate ansible inventory | localhost | 0:07:27.473631 | 2.57s

Change-Id: I5d62c3429d09397cbd9ba0e5a675d2f263e7e031
"}]
commit_message:
Inventory: Track seen nets, add/get new nets only

Before this change we fetched many duplicats of the
same network - i.e for every port even if the ports
are on a network we already collected. Subsequently
we got the subnet of all networks in the list which
contained many duplicates.

With this change we keep track of seen network's and
only get networks and subnets from the network service
once.

This reduces the number of calls to neutron by a huge
amount in larger scale deployments. In my 250 node
test enviornment for comparision.

OLD: Generate ansible inventory | localhost | 0:09:35.990553 | 124.56s
NEW: Generate ansible inventory | localhost | 0:07:27.473631 | 2.57s

commit_message:
Add strict validation about boolean parameters

This ensures the parameters used by if-else logic accept only boolean
values because non-boolean can result in unexpected behavior.

Change-Id: I666fea269663f219500c3a3ee748393c343b3f72
